Preface by Qian Dehong.

Dehong said: "Formerly, Nan Yuanshan published the Instructions for Practical Living in Yue, in two volumes. The second volume excerpted eight letters in the Master's own hand. Of the two letters 'Reply to Xu Chengzhi,' the Master himself said: 'The world has affirmed Zhu Xi and rejected Lu Xiangshan for so long that to reverse this in a single day is difficult. These two letters tentatively offer a mediating position, so that people may think it through for themselves.' Thus Yuanshan placed them at the beginning of the second volume, perhaps with this intention in mind. Now that the debate between Zhu Xi and Lu Xiangshan has long been clarified throughout the world, when I published the Master's Collected Writings, I placed these two letters in the Supplementary Collection to indicate that they were not his final position; therefore they are not included here. Of the remaining letters, those that most thoroughly explain the original substance of knowledge and action are the 'Reply Discussing Learning' and the four letters replying to Zhou Daotong, Lu Chengbo, and Ouyang Chongyi. The letter that most thoroughly explains 'investigation of things as the place where learners exert effort daily and visibly' is the 'Reply to Luo Zheng'an.' Throughout his life, braving the denunciations and attacks of the world, surviving countless mortal dangers, he anxiously never ceased lecturing and teaching, fearing only that people would not hear of this Way and would drift into utilitarianism and cunning, sinking daily into barbarism and bestiality without realizing it. His heart of forming one body with all things, ceaselessly laboring his whole life until death—this is the bitter devotion of sages from Confucius and Mencius onward, which even his own disciples could not fully appreciate. This sentiment is most thoroughly expressed in the first letter 'Reply to Nie Wenwei.' All these follow Yuanshan's original selection. But the passage revealing that 'there must be this undertaking' is precisely the effort of 'extending innate knowing'—clear, direct, and enabling people to find an immediate point of entry upon hearing it—this is most thoroughly expressed in the second letter to Wenwei, which I have therefore added. At that time of turmoil, Yuanshan was able to illuminate this Way with his own person, and though he ultimately suffered slander and dismissal, he was serenely content merely to have heard this teaching in his lifetime, without the slightest trace of indignation or resentment. In publishing this record, people see its great benefit to fellow seekers, but do not know how difficult the circumstances were in which it was produced. The selections and omissions I have made are determined by the demands of the time—I would not presume to add to or diminish what is therein."

Reply to Gu Dongqiao

Your letter states: "Recent scholars pursue the external and neglect the internal, being broad but lacking essentials. Therefore you, Master, have especially championed the single doctrine of 'making the intentions sincere,' a needle applied to the vital organs—truly a great benefit."

You have penetrated the ills of the time so clearly! But what then shall be done to remedy them? In that case, my own intention you have already expressed completely in a single phrase—what more is there to say? What more is there to say? As for the teaching of 'making the intentions sincere,' it has always been the primary doctrine by which the sages taught people to apply their effort. It is only that recent scholars have treated it as a secondary matter, so I have merely drawn it out and emphasized its importance somewhat—it is not something I myself have specially championed.

Your letter states: "But I fear the doctrine is set too high and the method too hasty. Later students imitating it may misconstrue it through vague resemblance, and it may inevitably fall into the Buddhist methods of 'illuminating the mind and seeing one's nature' and 'sudden awakening through concentration and wisdom.' It is no wonder that those who hear it are suspicious."

My teaching of investigation of things, extension of knowledge, making intentions sincere, and rectifying the mind is precisely directed at the learner's own mind, in the midst of daily affairs and activities. It involves concrete inquiry, practice, and real effort on solid ground—how many graduated steps, how much accumulation is involved! It is precisely the opposite of the talk of empty and sudden awakening. Those who hear it and are suspicious originally had no aspiration to become sages, and have never investigated the details. That they should be suspicious is no surprise. But with your own brilliance, you should surely understand it all at a single word. Yet you too say 'the doctrine is set too high and the method too hasty'—why is that?

Your letter states: "What you have explained about advancing knowledge and action together, not separating them into before and after, is precisely the method of the Doctrine of the Mean—'honoring the moral nature while following the path of inquiry and study'—the Way of mutual cultivation and reciprocal development, unifying internal and external, root and branch, in a single thread. Yet in the sequence of effort, there cannot be no difference of before and after. For example, one knows food and then eats, knows medicine and then drinks, knows clothing and then wears, knows the road and then walks. There has never been a case where, without first perceiving the object, one already performs the action. This too is but a matter of the slightest instant—I do not mean a rigid separation of levels, as if one knows today and acts only tomorrow."

Since you already say 'mutual cultivation and reciprocal development, unifying internal and external, root and branch, in a single thread,' then the teaching of advancing knowledge and action together should no longer be in doubt. Yet you also say 'in the sequence of effort, there cannot be no difference of before and after'—is this not self-contradictory? The examples of 'knowing food and then eating' and so forth are even more plainly evident. It is only that recent doctrines have obscured your vision so that you do not examine them carefully. A person must first have the desire to eat, and only then does he know food. The desire to eat is itself the intention—it is itself the beginning of action. Whether food tastes good or bad can only be known after it enters the mouth. How could one already know the taste of food without having tasted it? One must first have the desire to walk, and only then does one know the road. The desire to walk is itself the intention—it is itself the beginning of action. Whether the road is dangerous or easy can only be known after one has personally traversed it. How could one already know the danger or ease of the road without having personally traversed it? 'Knowing medicine and then drinking,' 'knowing clothing and then wearing'—by analogy with these, none can be doubted. If it were as you describe, that would be precisely what is called 'performing the action before perceiving the object.' You also say: 'This too is but a matter of the slightest instant—I do not mean a rigid separation of levels, as if one knows today and acts only tomorrow.' This too is not yet examined with full precision. Nevertheless, even going by your own account, the unity and simultaneous advancement of knowledge and action is something about which there can absolutely be no doubt.

Your letter states: "That true knowledge constitutes action, and that without action one cannot be said to have knowledge—as an urgent teaching for learners to ensure they devote themselves to personal practice, this is acceptable. But if one truly maintains that action is knowledge, I fear that by exclusively seeking in the original mind, one will neglect the principles of things, and there will inevitably be points of darkness and incomprehension. Would this not depart from the established method of the sages' school, in which knowledge and action advance together?"

The point where knowledge is true, earnest, and substantial is action; the point where action is luminously aware and precisely discerning is knowledge. The effort of knowledge and action fundamentally cannot be separated. It is only because later scholars split them into two separate endeavors, losing the original substance of knowledge and action, that there arose the teaching of their unity and simultaneous advancement. 'That true knowledge constitutes action, and that without action one cannot be said to have knowledge'—this can be seen from your own example of 'knowing food and then eating,' as I have briefly discussed above. Although this was stated urgently to remedy a deficiency, the substance of knowledge and action is originally like this. It is not that I have arbitrarily elevated one or suppressed the other, provisionally contriving this teaching for a temporary effect.

'Exclusively seeking in the original mind and thereby neglecting the principles of things'—this is precisely what happens to those who have lost their original mind. The principles of things are not external to our mind. To seek the principles of things external to our mind is to find no principles at all. To neglect the principles of things and seek our mind—what then would our mind be? The substance of the mind is the nature; the nature is principle. Therefore, when one has the mind of filial piety toward one's parents, there is the principle of filial piety; without the mind of filial piety, there is no principle of filial piety. When one has the mind of loyalty toward one's ruler, there is the principle of loyalty; without the mind of loyalty, there is no principle of loyalty. How could principle be external to our mind? Zhu Xi said: 'What constitutes human learning is simply the mind and principle. Though the mind is the master of one person, it truly governs all the principles under Heaven. Though principle is dispersed among the myriad things, it truly does not lie outside any single person's mind.' Yet in this very distinction between separating and uniting them, he could not avoid opening up for later scholars the deficiency of regarding the mind and principle as two. This is why later generations have the problem of 'exclusively seeking in the original mind and thereby neglecting the principles of things'—precisely because they do not know that the mind is principle. To seek the principles of things external to the mind—this is why there are points of darkness and incomprehension. This is Gaozi's doctrine that righteousness is external, which is why Mencius said he did not understand righteousness. The mind is one and only one. Spoken of in terms of its complete substance of compassion, it is called humaneness; in terms of its appropriateness, it is called righteousness; in terms of its orderly pattern, it is called principle. One cannot seek humaneness external to the mind, one cannot seek righteousness external to the mind—can one alone seek principle external to the mind? To seek principle external to the mind—this is why knowledge and action become two. To seek principle within our own mind—this is the teaching of the unity of knowledge and action in the school of the sages. What further doubt can you have?

Your letter states: "Your interpretation of the old text of the Great Learning, that 'extending knowledge' means extending the knowledge of the original substance—this is indeed the purport of Mencius's 'fully developing the mind,' and Zhu Xi also took the luminous spiritual awareness as the capacity of this mind. Yet 'fully developing the mind' depends upon 'knowing one's nature,' and 'extending knowledge' lies in 'the investigation of things.'"

'Fully developing the mind depends upon knowing one's nature; extending knowledge lies in the investigation of things'—this statement is correct. However, tracing back your underlying intention, the reason you make this statement still contains something not yet clear. Zhu Xi took 'fully developing the mind, knowing one's nature, and knowing Heaven' to correspond to 'things investigated, knowledge extended'; 'preserving the mind, nourishing one's nature, and serving Heaven' to correspond to 'intentions made sincere, mind rectified, self cultivated'; and 'not being of two minds about longevity and premature death, cultivating oneself to await destiny' to correspond to 'knowledge fully attained, humaneness fully realized—the affairs of the sage.' My own view is precisely the reverse of Zhu Xi's. 'Fully developing the mind, knowing one's nature, and knowing Heaven' is the affair of the sage—born knowing and acting with natural ease. 'Preserving the mind, nourishing one's nature, and serving Heaven' is the affair of the worthy—learning and then knowing, acting for advantage. 'Not being of two minds about longevity and premature death, cultivating oneself to await destiny' is the affair of the student—knowing through difficulty, acting through strenuous effort. How can one exclusively take 'fully developing the mind and knowing one's nature' as knowledge, and 'preserving the mind and nourishing one's nature' as action? Upon suddenly hearing this, you will surely be greatly startled. Yet there is truly nothing doubtful in it—let me explain it to you.

The substance of the mind is the nature; the source of the nature is Heaven. To be able to fully develop one's mind is to be able to fully realize one's nature. The Doctrine of the Mean says: 'Only the one of utmost sincerity under Heaven can fully realize his nature.' It also says: 'To know the transforming and nourishing processes of Heaven and Earth, to be tested against spiritual beings without any doubt—that is knowing Heaven.' Only the sage can do this. Therefore I say: 'This is the affair of the sage—born knowing and acting with natural ease.'

One who preserves his mind is one who has not yet fully developed his mind; therefore he must add the effort of preservation. Only after preserving it for a long time, until it is no longer necessary to make the effort of preservation and it is naturally never lost, can one then advance to speak of fully developing it. The 'knowing' in 'knowing Heaven' is like the 'knowing' in 'knowing the prefecture' or 'knowing the county.' 'Knowing the prefecture' means that all affairs of the prefecture are one's own affairs; 'knowing the county' means that all affairs of the county are one's own affairs. This is being one with Heaven. 'Serving Heaven' is like a son serving his father or a minister serving his ruler—one is still two with Heaven. What Heaven has conferred upon me is the mind and the nature. I merely preserve them without daring to lose them, nourish them without daring to harm them—as it is said, 'Parents give birth to one whole, and the child returns it whole.' Therefore I say: 'This is the affair of the worthy—learning and then knowing, acting for advantage.'

As for 'not being of two minds about longevity and premature death,' this represents yet another stage beyond 'preserving one's mind.' One who preserves his mind, though he has not yet fully developed it, is already single-minded about doing good. When there are times of not preserving it, he simply preserves it again and that is all. Now to require him to 'not be of two minds about longevity and premature death' implies that he is still of two minds on account of longevity and premature death. If he is still of two minds on account of longevity and premature death, then his mind for doing good is not yet single. Preservation is still not fully possible for him—how then can one speak of fully developing? For now, one simply asks him not to let longevity and premature death divide his mind from doing good, saying: 'Death, life, longevity, and premature death are all matters of fixed destiny. I will simply be single-minded about doing good and cultivate myself to await Heaven's command—that is all.' This means that in ordinary times he does not yet know where Heaven's command lies. 'Serving Heaven,' though still being two with Heaven, already truly knows where Heaven's command lies and merely respectfully obeys it. As for the word 'await,' this means one does not yet truly know where Heaven's command lies and still has something to await. Therefore it is called 'establishing one's destiny.' 'Establishing' here means 'founding' or 'creating,' as in 'establishing virtue,' 'establishing words,' 'establishing merit,' or 'establishing a name.' Whatever is said to be 'established' always refers to something that did not previously exist and is now first founded. This is what Confucius meant by 'Without knowing destiny, one has no means of being a gentleman.' Therefore I say: 'This is the affair of the student—knowing through difficulty, acting through strenuous effort.'

Now to take 'fully developing the mind, knowing one's nature, and knowing Heaven' as corresponding to 'investigation of things and extension of knowledge,' and to suddenly demand of beginning students, who have not yet achieved single-mindedness, the sage's affair of being born knowing and acting with natural ease—this is like grasping at wind and catching shadows, leaving them utterly bewildered with no idea where to direct their minds. How close this comes to 'leading the whole world astray'! The ills of today's 'extending knowledge and investigating things' are already plainly visible. What you called 'pursuing the external and neglecting the internal, being broad but lacking essentials'—is this not precisely such an excess? This is the most critical point in all learning. If one errs here, there will be no direction in which one does not err. This is why I have braved the ridicule of the whole world and forgotten the danger of being condemned and punished, ceaselessly speaking out—because I cannot contain myself.

Your letter states: "I have heard that in speaking to students, you say that the doctrine of 'approaching things and exhausting their principles' is also a case of 'indulging in things and losing one's purpose.' You also select Zhu Xi's few statements about 'preferring the concise over the complex' and 'nourishing the root source,' presenting them to students as his settled views of his later years. I fear this too is incorrect."

What Zhu Xi meant by 'investigation of things' is 'approaching things and exhausting their principles.' To approach things and exhaust their principles is to seek what is called the fixed principle in each and every thing. This is to use our mind to seek principle in each and every thing—splitting the mind and principle into two. To seek principle in each and every thing is like seeking the principle of filial piety in one's parents. If one seeks the principle of filial piety in one's parents, then is the principle of filial piety ultimately in our mind, or is it ultimately in our parents' bodies? Supposing it is ultimately in our parents' bodies, then after our parents have died, does our mind thereupon lack the principle of filial piety? When one sees a child about to fall into a well, one must have the principle of compassion—is this principle of compassion ultimately in the child's body, or in the innate knowing of our own mind? Perhaps one ought not to follow the child into the well; perhaps one may rescue the child by hand—these are all what is called principle. Are they ultimately in the child's body, or do they ultimately come from the innate knowing of our own mind? Extending this to all things, the principles of the myriad things are all the same. From this one can see that splitting the mind and principle into two is wrong.

Splitting the mind and principle into two—this is Gaozi's doctrine that righteousness is external, which Mencius profoundly refuted. 'Pursuing the external and neglecting the internal, being broad but lacking essentials'—you yourself already know this. What then is the reason for it? To call it 'indulging in things and losing one's purpose'—would you still say this goes too far? As for what I mean by 'extending knowledge and investigating things,' it is extending the innate knowing of our mind to each and every thing. The innate knowing of our mind is what is called 'the Principle of Heaven.' When we extend the Principle of Heaven that is the innate knowing of our mind to each and every thing, then each and every thing obtains its principle. Extending the innate knowing of our mind—that is extending knowledge. Each and every thing obtaining its principle—that is the investigation of things. This unites the mind and principle as one. Once the mind and principle are united as one, then all that I have said before, together with Zhu Xi's later-year discussions, can all be understood without needing to be stated.

Your letter states: "The substance of the human mind is originally never unilluminated, yet being constrained by material endowment and obscured by things, few avoid becoming benighted. Without learning, questioning, thinking, and discerning to illuminate the principles of the world, the triggers of good and evil, the distinctions between truth and falsehood, cannot be perceived by oneself. If one indulges one's feelings and acts willfully, the harm is beyond description."

This passage seems largely correct but is actually not so, for it carries forward the deficiencies of the old doctrines. It must be distinguished. Questioning, thinking, discerning, and acting are all part of learning. There has never been learning without action. For instance, to speak of learning filial piety, one must serve one's parents with labor and provide for them, personally practicing the way of filial piety, before it can be called learning. How could merely discussing it in empty words and hearsay be called learning filial piety? Learning archery requires drawing the bow, nocking the arrow, pulling to full draw, and hitting the target. Learning calligraphy requires spreading the paper, holding the brush, and applying ink. In all learning under Heaven, there is none that can be called learning without action. Thus from the very beginning, learning already is action. 'Earnestness' means substantial, solid effort. Having already acted, to be earnest in one's action and never cease in one's effort—that is all. When learning cannot be without doubt, then there is questioning. Questioning is learning; it is action. When there still cannot be no doubt, then there is thinking. Thinking is learning; it is action. When there still cannot be no doubt, then there is discerning. Discerning is learning; it is action. Having discerned clearly, having thought carefully, having questioned thoroughly, having learned capably, one then ceaselessly continues one's effort—this is called earnest action. It does not mean that after learning, questioning, thinking, and discerning, one only then puts it into action.

Therefore, speaking in terms of seeking competence in affairs, it is called learning; in terms of seeking resolution of doubts, it is called questioning; in terms of seeking comprehension of explanations, it is called thinking; in terms of seeking precision of examination, it is called discerning; in terms of seeking to tread upon the real, it is called action. Analyzed by function there are five, but united in substance they are one and the same. This is the unity of the mind and principle, the simultaneous advancement of knowledge and action, which differs from later doctrines precisely in this.

Now you single out learning, questioning, thinking, and discerning to exhaust the principles of the world, without mentioning earnest action. This is to take learning, questioning, thinking, and discerning exclusively as knowledge, and to hold that exhausting principle involves no action. But is there learning under Heaven without action? Is there anyone who can be said to exhaust principle without action? Cheng Hao said: 'Simply exhausting principle already fully realizes the nature and reaches destiny.' Therefore one must be humane to the utmost before one can be said to exhaust the principle of humaneness; one must be righteous to the utmost before one can be said to exhaust the principle of righteousness. Being humane to the utmost, one fully realizes the nature of humaneness; being righteous to the utmost, one fully realizes the nature of righteousness. Learning that reaches the point of exhausting principle has reached its utmost—yet you say it has not yet been put into action. Is there such a thing under Heaven? Therefore, knowing that the absence of action cannot be called learning, one also knows that the absence of action cannot be called exhausting principle. Knowing that the absence of action cannot be called exhausting principle, one then knows that knowledge and action are united and advance simultaneously, and cannot be divided into two separate stages.

The principles of the myriad things do not lie outside our mind. Yet if one insists on 'exhausting the principles of the world,' this is to consider the innate knowing of our mind as insufficient, and to necessarily seek outward throughout the vastness of the world to supplement and augment it—this is still splitting the mind and principle into two. The effort of learning, questioning, thinking, discerning, and earnest action, even if in difficulty one must apply a hundred times the effort of others, and if expanded to its utmost reaches fully realizing the nature and knowing Heaven—all this is merely extending the innate knowing of our mind, nothing more. Beyond innate knowing, could there be even a hair's breadth to add? Now if one insists on 'exhausting the principles of the world' and does not know to turn and seek within one's own mind, then as for what you call 'the triggers of good and evil, the distinctions between truth and falsehood'—apart from the innate knowing of our mind, where else would one apply one's examination? What you call being 'constrained by material endowment and obscured by things'—it constrains this and obscures this, nothing else. Now if one wishes to remove this obscuration but does not know to exert effort here, and instead seeks externally—this is like a person whose eyes are not clear: instead of taking medicine to treat his eyes, he stumbles about blindly seeking clarity outside. How could clarity be obtained from without? The harm of 'indulging one's feelings and acting willfully' is also nothing more than failing to examine the Principle of Heaven precisely in the innate knowing of this mind. This is truly a case where the difference of a hair's breadth leads to an error of a thousand miles. It cannot be left undistinguished. I hope you will not think my argument too severe.

Your letter states: "To teach people with extending knowledge and illuminating virtue, while cautioning them against approaching things and exhausting their principles—does this truly mean that a benighted person, sitting alone in deep seclusion, hearing no instruction, can thereby achieve knowledge extended and virtue illuminated? Even if in stillness he has some perception and slightly apprehends his original nature, this would still be but the heterodox view of useless concentration and wisdom. Could he truly know past and present, comprehend the changes of affairs, and apply this practically to the governance of the state and the world? As for your saying 'Knowledge is the substance of the intention; things are the function of the intention; investigating things is like the 'rectifying' in rectifying the ruler's errant mind'—though the words show transcendent insight and independent originality without following old views, I fear they may not yet accord with the Way."

My discussion of extending knowledge and investigating things is precisely exhausting principle. I have never cautioned people against exhausting principle or instructed them to sit in deep seclusion doing nothing at all. If one speaks of 'approaching things and exhausting their principles' in the sense of 'pursuing the external and neglecting the internal' as previously described, then that indeed cannot be accepted. If a benighted person can, in every affair and thing, precisely examine the Principle of Heaven in this mind and thereby extend his innate knowing in its original state, then though dull he will become brilliant, though weak he will become strong. The great root will be established and the universal Way will be practiced. The nine standard regulations and all such matters can be threaded together on a single strand with nothing left out. What further worry could there be about lacking practical application? As for those followers of empty nothingness and quiet stillness, it is precisely because they cannot, in every affair and thing, precisely examine the Principle of Heaven in this mind and extend their innate knowing in its original state that they abandon human relationships and take annihilation and emptiness as the constant. This is why ultimately they cannot govern family, state, and world. Who would claim that the sage's learning of exhausting principle and fully realizing the nature has such deficiencies?

The mind is the master of the body. The luminous spiritual awareness of the mind is what is called the innate knowing in its original state. When this luminous spiritual awareness of innate knowing responds to stimulus and is activated, it is called the intention. Where there is knowledge, only then is there intention; without knowledge, there is no intention. Is knowledge not the substance of the intention? What the intention is applied to must have its object; the object is an affair. If the intention is applied to serving parents, then serving parents is an object. If the intention is applied to governing the people, then governing the people is an object. If the intention is applied to reading, then reading is an object. If the intention is applied to adjudicating lawsuits, then adjudicating lawsuits is an object. In whatever the intention is applied to, there is never a case without an object. Where there is such an intention, there is such an object; where there is no such intention, there is no such object. Are objects not the function of the intention?

As for the meaning of the character 'ge' (investigate/rectify), there are cases where it is glossed as 'to arrive at,' as in 'arriving at the ancestral temple of King Wen' or 'the Miao people came to submit'—these use the gloss 'arrive.' However, 'arriving at the ancestral temple of King Wen' requires pure filial devotion and sincere reverence, with nothing between the seen and unseen realms that does not obtain its proper principle, before one can speak of 'arriving.' The stubbornness of the Miao was overcome only through the spread of civil virtue, so this also contains the sense of 'rectifying'—it cannot be exhausted by the gloss 'arrive' alone. In cases like 'rectifying his errant mind' and 'the great minister rectifies the ruler's errant mind,' the meaning throughout is 'correcting what is incorrect to restore it to correctness,' and the gloss 'arrive' will not work. Moreover, in the Great Learning's 'investigation of things,' how do we know it should not be glossed as 'rectify' rather than necessarily meaning 'arrive'? Those who take it as 'arrive' must say 'arriving at the uttermost of the principles of things' before their interpretation is coherent. The crux of their method lies entirely in the single word 'exhaust'; the ground of their effort lies entirely in the single word 'principle.' If one removes the word 'exhaust' above and the word 'principle' below, and simply reads 'extending knowledge lies in arriving-at things'—can this be coherent?

'Exhausting principle and fully realizing the nature' is the established instruction of the sage, found in the Appended Remarks of the Book of Changes. If the doctrine of 'investigation of things' were indeed identical in meaning to 'exhausting principle,' why did the sage not simply say 'extending knowledge lies in exhausting principle,' instead of using this incomplete and convoluted expression that would open up later abuses? The Great Learning's doctrine of 'investigation of things,' while largely similar in purport to the Appended Remarks' 'exhausting principle,' has subtle distinctions. 'Exhausting principle' encompasses the efforts of investigating, extending, making sincere, and rectifying as a whole. Therefore, when one speaks of 'exhausting principle,' the efforts of investigating, extending, making sincere, and rectifying are all contained within it. When one speaks of 'investigating things,' one must also mention extending knowledge, making intentions sincere, and rectifying the mind before the method is complete and thorough. Now to single out 'investigating things' and immediately call it 'exhausting principle'—this is why 'exhausting principle' has been exclusively assigned to knowledge, and 'investigating things' is said to contain no action. Not only does this miss the purport of 'investigating things,' but it also distorts the meaning of 'exhausting principle.' This is why later learning has split knowledge and action into two successive stages, becoming daily more fragmented and disjointed, and why the sage's learning has become increasingly obscured. The beginning of this truly lies here. You too have inevitably been carried along by accumulated habits; to say that my view 'may not yet accord with the Way' is not excessive.

Your letter states: "To say that the effort of extending knowledge consists in knowing how to keep parents warm in winter and cool in summer, how to provide for them—and that this is 'making the intentions sincere,' with no separate thing called 'investigation of things'—this too, I fear, is incorrect."

This is something you yourself have surmised about my view and constructed into this statement—it is not what I have told you. If it were truly as you say, could it possibly be coherent?

My own view is as follows: The desire to keep parents warm and cool, the desire to provide for them—this is what is called 'the intention,' but it cannot yet be called 'making the intentions sincere.' One must actually carry out the intention of keeping parents warm and cool and providing for them, striving for self-satisfaction without self-deception—only then can it be called 'making the intentions sincere.'

Knowing how to achieve the proper measure of keeping parents warm and cool, knowing how to achieve the proper standard of providing for them—this is what is called 'knowledge,' but it cannot yet be called 'extending knowledge.' One must extend the knowledge of how to achieve the proper measure of keeping parents warm and cool, and actually keep them warm and cool accordingly; extend the knowledge of how to achieve the proper standard of providing for them, and actually provide for them accordingly—only then can it be called 'extending knowledge.'

The affairs of keeping parents warm and cool, the affairs of providing for them—these are what is called 'things,' but they cannot yet be called 'investigation of things.' One must, in the affair of keeping parents warm and cool, act exactly as one's innate knowing knows one ought to achieve the proper measure of warmth and coolness, without the slightest deficiency. In the affair of providing for parents, one must act exactly as one's innate knowing knows one ought to achieve the proper standard of provision, without the slightest deficiency. Only then can it be called 'investigation of things.'

When the thing of keeping parents warm and cool is investigated, only then is the innate knowing of keeping parents warm and cool first extended. When the thing of providing for parents is investigated, only then is the innate knowing of providing for parents first extended. Therefore it says: 'When things are investigated, only then is knowledge extended.' When one extends the innate knowing of keeping parents warm and cool, only then is the intention of keeping parents warm and cool first made sincere. When one extends the innate knowing of providing for parents, only then is the intention of providing for parents first made sincere. Therefore it says: 'When knowledge is extended, only then are the intentions made sincere.' This is my teaching of 'making intentions sincere, extending knowledge, and investigating things.' If you think it through more carefully, there should be nothing left to doubt.

Your letter states: "The great outlines of the Way are easy to understand clearly—this is what is meant by 'innate knowing and innate ability, which even the foolish man and foolish woman can share.' But as for the details and contingencies, and the errors of a thousand miles from a hair's breadth difference, these must be waited upon through learning before they can be known. Now, speaking of filial piety in terms of keeping parents warm in winter and cool in summer and paying regular visits—who does not know this? But when it comes to Shun's marrying without informing his parents, King Wu's raising an army before burying his father, the difference between nourishing one's parents' will and merely nourishing their mouths, between accepting light punishment and fleeing severe punishment, and such matters as cutting flesh from one's own thigh or building a mourning hut by the grave—between ordinary and extraordinary situations, between excess and deficiency—one must discuss right and wrong to establish the basis for handling affairs. Only then will the substance of the mind be unobscured and one will not err when confronting situations."

'The great outlines of the Way are easy to understand clearly'—this is indeed so. Yet later scholars have neglected what is easy to understand and not followed it, instead seeking what is difficult to understand as their learning. This is what is meant by 'the Way is near, but they seek it afar; the task is easy, but they seek it in the difficult.' Mencius said: 'The Way is like a broad road—is it really hard to know? The trouble is simply that people do not follow it.' Innate knowing and innate ability—the foolish man and woman share them equally with the sage. The difference is only that the sage can extend his innate knowing while the foolish man and woman cannot—this is what divides the sage from the foolish. How could the sage not know the details and contingencies? He simply does not take these exclusively as his learning. What he calls learning is precisely extending his innate knowing to examine the Principle of Heaven in this mind with precision—and in this he differs from the learning of later ages. You have not yet had time for the true effort of extending knowledge, yet you anxiously worry about such details. This is precisely the error of 'seeking what is difficult to understand as one's learning.'

Innate knowing in relation to details and contingencies is like the carpenter's square and ruler in relation to squares and circles, lengths and breadths. The details and contingencies cannot be predetermined, just as squares, circles, lengths, and breadths cannot be exhausted. Therefore, if the carpenter's square is truly established, one cannot be deceived about squares and circles, and all the squares and circles under Heaven become available for use. If the ruler is truly laid out, one cannot be deceived about lengths and breadths, and all the lengths and breadths under Heaven become available for use. If innate knowing is truly extended, one cannot be deceived about details and contingencies, and all the details and contingencies under Heaven can be responded to. If one does not examine the difference of a thousand miles at the subtle point of a single thought in the innate knowing of our mind, where else would one apply one's learning? This is to try to determine all the squares and circles under Heaven without a carpenter's square, to try to exhaust all the lengths and breadths under Heaven without a ruler. I foresee that such a person will be confused and erratic, laboring daily without achievement.

You say: 'Speaking of filial piety in terms of keeping parents warm and cool and paying regular visits—who does not know this?' Yet those who can extend that knowledge are few. If one says that roughly knowing the ceremonies of keeping parents warm and cool and paying visits already constitutes extending one's knowledge, then all who know a ruler ought to be humane can be said to have extended their knowledge of humaneness, and all who know a minister ought to be loyal can be said to have extended their knowledge of loyalty. Then who under Heaven is not one who extends knowledge? From this we can see that extending knowledge must lie in action, and that without action one cannot be said to extend knowledge—this is now clear. Is not the substance of the unity of knowledge and action all the more manifest?

As for Shun's marrying without informing his parents—was there already before Shun's time someone who had married without informing his parents to serve as a precedent, so that Shun could consult some canon or ask some person and act accordingly? Or did he rather seek in the true knowledge of a single thought of his own mind, weigh the appropriateness of the greater and lesser considerations, and find it unavoidable? As for King Wu's raising an army before burying his father—was there already before Wu's time someone who had raised an army before burying his father to serve as a precedent, so that Wu could consult some canon or ask some person and act accordingly? Or did he rather seek in the innate knowing of a single thought of his own mind, weigh the appropriateness of the greater and lesser considerations, and find it unavoidable? If Shun's mind had not been genuinely devoted to the concern of being without posterity, or if Wu's mind had not been genuinely devoted to the concern of rescuing the people, then marrying without informing one's parents or raising an army before burying one's father would be the greatest unfiliality and disloyalty. Yet later people, instead of devoting themselves to extending their innate knowing and examining righteous principle precisely in the responsiveness of this mind to situations, wish to discuss in empty abstraction such extraordinary and ordinary cases, seizing upon them as the basis for handling affairs and seeking to avoid error when confronting situations—how far removed this is! The remaining examples can all be inferred by analogy. From this, the learning of extending knowledge practiced by the ancients can be understood.

Your letter states: "To say that the Great Learning's 'investigation of things' exclusively seeks in the original mind may still be forced into coherence. But as for what is recorded in the Six Classics and Four Books about 'hearing much and seeing much,' 'the words and deeds of the ancients,' 'loving antiquity and being diligent in seeking,' 'learning broadly and questioning carefully,' 'reviewing the old and knowing the new,' 'learning broadly and explaining in detail,' and 'being fond of questioning and examining what is near'—these all clearly seek in the realm of affairs and activities, drawing upon discussion and discourse. The steps of applying effort certainly cannot be confused."

The meaning of 'investigation of things' has already been explained in detail above. The doubt about 'forcing into coherence' should no longer require further resolution.

As for 'hearing much and seeing much,' this was Confucius's response to Zizhang, who pursued the external and aimed high, seeking to make broad hearing and seeing his entire learning without being able to seek within his own mind, setting aside what was doubtful. This is why his words and actions were not free from blame and regret—his so-called hearing and seeing only served his pursuit of the external and aiming high. This was meant to remedy Zizhang's problem of excessive hearing and seeing, not to teach him that this constituted learning. The Master once said: 'There may be those who act without knowledge; I am not one of them.' This is precisely the meaning of Mencius's 'the mind that distinguishes right and wrong is something all people possess.' These words precisely illuminate that the innate knowing of the moral nature does not derive from hearing and seeing. If one says 'hearing much, selecting what is good and following it; seeing much and noting it'—this is to seek exclusively in the peripheral realm of hearing and seeing, already falling into the second level. Therefore he said: 'This is the next level.' If the knowledge of hearing and seeing is called the next level, then what does 'the higher level of knowledge' refer to? From this one can glimpse where the sages' school directs the effort of extending knowledge. The Master said to Zigong: 'Si, do you take me to be one who learns much and remembers it all? No—I thread it all on one strand.' If learning truly consisted of 'learning much and remembering,' then why would the Master make this misleading statement to deceive Zigong? 'Threading it all on one strand'—what is this if not extending one's innate knowing?

The Book of Changes says: 'The gentleman learns much of the words and deeds of the ancients in order to accumulate his virtue.' If one's heart is set on accumulating virtue, then all that one learns of the words and deeds of the ancients—which of these is not an act of accumulating virtue? This is precisely the effort of the unity of knowledge and action.

'Loving antiquity and being diligent in seeking'—this is loving the learning of the ancients and diligently seeking the principle of this mind. The mind is principle. Learning is learning this mind; seeking is seeking this mind. Mencius said: 'The way of learning is nothing else—it is simply seeking the lost mind.' This is not like the broad memorization and recitation of the ancients' words by later ages, taking that as 'loving antiquity,' while anxiously seeking only the tools of fame and profit externally.

'Learning broadly and questioning carefully'—this has been fully addressed above.

'Reviewing the old and knowing the new'—Zhu Xi himself also attributed 'reviewing the old' to 'honoring the moral nature.' How can the moral nature be sought externally? That 'knowing the new' must proceed from 'reviewing the old,' and that 'reviewing the old' is precisely the means of 'knowing the new'—this can also verify that knowledge and action are not two separate stages.

'Learning broadly and explaining in detail'—this is 'in order to return to the essential.' Without the phrase 'returning to the essential,' what would 'learning broadly and explaining in detail' amount to?

Shun's 'being fond of questioning and examining what is near'—this was solely in order to 'use the mean' and bring his 'refinement and singleness' to bear upon the mind of the Way. The mind of the Way is what is called innate knowing.

The gentleman's learning—when has it ever departed from affairs and activities or abandoned discussion and discourse? But his engagement with affairs and discourse is entirely the effort of the unity of knowledge and action, precisely in order to extend the innate knowing of his original mind. It is not like those in the world who merely engage in oral and aural discussion, taking that as knowledge, splitting knowledge and action into two things, and claiming there are steps and sequences between them.

Your letter states: "Yang Zhu's and Mo Di's distortions of humaneness and righteousness, the village worthy's corruption of loyalty and trustworthiness, the abdications of Yao, Shun, and Zizhi, the depositions by Tang, Wu, and Xiang Yu, the regencies of the Duke of Zhou, Wang Mang, and Cao Cao—without verification, how can one decide which to follow? Moreover, regarding changes in ancient and modern affairs, rites and music, names and objects—if one has never studied and examined them, then should the state wish to establish the Hall of Light, build the academy, regulate the calendar and musical pitches, or compose the Feng and Shan sacrificial ceremonies, where would one apply one's knowledge? Therefore the Analects says: 'What one is born knowing' refers to moral principles. As for rites and music, names and objects, and ancient and modern changes of affairs, one must wait upon learning and only then can one verify the reality of one's conduct. This may be called a settled conclusion."

The distinctions among Yang Zhu, Mo Di, the village worthy, Yao, Shun, Zizhi, Tang, Wu, Xiang Yu, the Duke of Zhou, Wang Mang, and Cao Cao that you mention can largely be inferred by analogy from the earlier discussion of Shun and Wu. As for the doubt about ancient and modern changes of affairs, the earlier discussion of innate knowing has already offered the analogy of the carpenter's square and ruler, which should suffice without much more elaboration. As for the Hall of Light, the academy, and such matters, it seems there is still something that cannot go unsaid. However, the explanation would be very long, so let me simply take your own words and seek what is correct in them. Then your confusion may perhaps be somewhat resolved.

The institution of the Hall of Light first appears in Lu Buwei's Monthly Ordinances and the commentaries of Han dynasty scholars. In the Six Classics and Four Books, it is never discussed in detail. Were Lu Buwei and the Han scholars more knowledgeable than the sages and worthies of the Three Dynasties? In the time of King Xuan of Qi, the Hall of Light had not yet been destroyed. In the reigns of Kings You and Li, the Hall of Light of the Zhou was still intact. Yao and Shun had thatched roofs and earthen steps—the institution of the Hall of Light may not have been fully developed—yet this did not prevent good governance. The Hall of Light under Kings You and Li was still the same as under Kings Wen, Wu, Cheng, and Kang—yet it could not save them from disorder. Why? If one can 'extend the mind that cannot bear others' suffering to implement governance that cannot bear others' suffering,' then even thatched roofs and earthen steps are a Hall of Light. If one has the minds of Kings You and Li and implements their governance, then even a Hall of Light is merely the place from which tyranny issues. Emperor Wu first instituted it in the Han, and Empress Wu elaborately constructed it in the Tang—how was their governance?

The Son of Heaven's academy is called the Biyong; the feudal lords' academy is called the Pangong. Both are named after geographical features they imitate. Yet in the learning of the Three Dynasties, the essential purpose was entirely to illuminate human relationships—not to place importance on whether something is circular or semi-circular. Confucius said: 'If a person is not humane, what can he do with rites? If a person is not humane, what can he do with music?' To create rites and compose music, one must possess the virtue of centrality and harmony, with one's voice serving as the standard of pitch and one's body serving as the standard of measure—only then can one speak of this. As for the peripheral matters of instruments and numbers, these are the concern of music officials; the keeping of sacrificial records is the duty of the invocators and scribes. Therefore Zengzi said: 'What the gentleman values in the Way are three things; as for the ceremonial vessels, the proper officials handle them.' When Yao commanded the Xi and He families to 'respectfully follow the expansive heavens and calculate the sun, moon, and stars,' the emphasis was on 'respectfully teaching the people about the seasons.' When Shun handled the jade armillary sphere, the emphasis was on 'regulating the seven celestial bodies.' All this was anxiously implementing the governance of nourishing the people with a heart of humaneness toward the people. The root of clarifying the calendar and illuminating the seasons indeed lies here.

The calendrical science of Xi and He—Gao Yao and Qi may not have been capable of it; Yu and Ji may not have been capable of it. Even Yao and Shun, whose 'knowledge did not extend to everything'—even they may not have been capable of it. Yet down to the present day, following the methods of Xi and He and refining them generation after generation, even those of narrow knowledge and petty cleverness, even shallow and crude practitioners of astrology, can calculate and predict without error. Does this mean that the people of narrow knowledge and petty cleverness of later ages are wiser than Yu, Ji, Yao, and Shun?

The theory of the Feng and Shan sacrifices is all the more baseless. These were devised by fawning flatterers of later ages to curry favor with their superiors, promoting extravagance to inflame the ruler's ambition and squander the state's resources. They represent the height of shamelessness in deceiving Heaven and defrauding people. They are what the gentleman does not discuss—the reason why Sima Xiangru has been criticized by the world through the ages. That you should consider this something Confucian scholars ought to study—have you perhaps not thought this through?

What makes the sage a sage is that he is born knowing. Yet the interpreter of the Analects says: 'What one is born knowing refers only to moral principles. As for rites and music, names and objects, and ancient and modern changes of affairs, one must wait upon learning and only then can one verify the reality of one's conduct.' If rites, music, names, and objects are truly relevant to the work of becoming a sage, yet even the sage must wait upon learning before he can know them, then the sage cannot be said to be 'born knowing.' If the sage is called 'born knowing' with exclusive reference to moral principles and not rites, music, names, and objects, then rites, music, names, and objects are irrelevant to the work of becoming a sage. If the sage is called 'born knowing' with exclusive reference to moral principles and not rites, music, names, and objects, then those who 'learn and then know' should also only need to learn this moral principle; those who 'know through difficulty' should also only need to know this moral principle through difficulty. Now if a learner studying to become a sage cannot yet 'learn and know' what the sage is able to know, but instead anxiously seeks to know what the sage is unable to know and takes that as learning—is this not losing the method by which one aspires to sagehood? All of this merely analyzes and resolves the particular points of your confusion, and has not yet reached the fundamental discussion of 'pulling up the root and blocking the source.'

If the fundamental discussion of 'pulling up the root and blocking the source' is not made clear to the world, then those who study to become sages will find it daily more complex and difficult. People will sink into barbarism and bestiality yet still consider themselves practitioners of the sage's learning.

Even if my teaching is perhaps briefly illuminated for a time, in the end it will thaw in the west only to freeze harder in the east, clear like mist in front only to gather like clouds behind. I shall cry out ceaselessly in danger and exhaustion until death, yet ultimately be unable to help the world even a fraction. The mind of the sage takes Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things as one body. He looks upon all people under Heaven without distinguishing outer and inner, far and near—all who have blood and breath are his own brothers and beloved children, whom he wishes to secure, perfect, and nurture, thereby fulfilling his vision of forming one body with all things.

The minds of people under Heaven were originally no different from the sage's. It is only that they are separated by the selfishness of ego and obstructed by the obscuration of material desires, so that what is great becomes small and what is open becomes blocked. Each person has his own mind, to the point where some regard their own fathers, sons, and brothers as enemies. The sage was troubled by this. Therefore he extended his humaneness of forming one body with Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things to teach the world, enabling all to overcome their selfishness, remove their obscurations, and restore the commonality of the mind's original substance. The great outline of this teaching is what Yao, Shun, and Yu transmitted to one another—'The mind of the Way is subtle; be refined, be single-minded; hold faithfully to the Mean'—and its specific items are what Shun commanded Qi to teach: 'Between father and son there is affection; between ruler and minister there is righteousness; between husband and wife there is distinction; between elder and younger there is precedence; between friends there is trustworthiness'—these five and nothing more. In the ages of Tang, Yu, and the Three Dynasties, teachers taught nothing but this, and students studied nothing but this. At that time, no one held divergent views, no household practiced differently. Those who were at ease in this were called sages; those who exerted themselves in it were called worthies; those who turned away from it, even if brilliant as Zhu, were called unworthy. Down to the common people of neighborhoods and villages, the farmers, artisans, and merchants of the humblest station—none lacked this learning. Their sole concern was to perfect their moral character. Why? There was no distraction of miscellaneous hearing and seeing, no burden of rote memorization, no excess of florid literary composition, no pursuit of utilitarian advantage. They simply practiced filial piety toward parents, respect toward elders, and trustworthiness toward friends, restoring the commonality of the mind's original substance. This was something inherent in their nature, not something borrowed from without. Who then could not do it?

Within the schools, the sole concern was the perfection of moral character. Those whose talents differed—some excelling in rites and music, some in governance and teaching, some in agriculture and irrigation—were, on the basis of their already-perfected character, enabled to further refine their abilities within the schools. When they were selected for their virtue and appointed to office, they served in their positions for life without change. Those who employed them knew only the shared commitment of common purpose, evaluating whether talents matched positions, without regarding rank as important or trivial, or labor as desirable or undesirable. Those who served likewise knew only the shared commitment of common purpose—if their abilities suited the position, they would serve their entire lives in demanding posts without considering it toilsome, content in humble positions without considering it demeaning. At that time, all people under Heaven lived in joyful harmony, regarding each other as members of one family. Those of lesser talent and endowment were content in their allotted roles as farmers, artisans, and merchants, each diligent in their occupations, mutually sustaining and nourishing one another, without any thought of aspiring above their station or envying the external.

Those of exceptional talent, like Gao Yao, Kui, Ji, and Qi, came forth and each contributed their abilities. It was like the affairs of a single household: some managing food and clothing, some facilitating exchange, some preparing tools and implements—all pooling their counsel and combining their strength to fulfill the wish of supporting those above and nurturing those below, fearing only that those charged with responsibilities might be negligent and thereby add to their own burden. Thus Ji was diligent in agriculture without being ashamed of not knowing how to teach—he regarded Qi's excellence in teaching as his own excellence in teaching. Kui managed music without being ashamed of not understanding rites—he regarded Yi's mastery of rites as his own mastery of rites. This was because their learning of the mind was pure and luminous, enabling them to fully realize their humaneness of forming one body with all things. Their spiritual energy flowed freely and their purposes communicated without obstruction, with no division between self and other, no barrier between things and me. It is like a single body: the eyes see, the ears hear, the hands hold, the feet walk—all serving the use of one body. The eyes are not ashamed of lacking hearing, and what the ears take in, the eyes necessarily attend to. The feet are not ashamed of lacking grip, and where the hands reach, the feet necessarily advance. This is because the vital energy circulates fully and the blood flows smoothly—therefore an itch or an ache, a breath in or out, is felt and responded to spiritually, with a wordless, wonderful understanding. The learning of the sage is therefore supremely easy and supremely simple, easy to know and easy to follow, easy to learn and easy to accomplish—precisely because the great essential lies solely in restoring the commonality of the mind's original substance, and technical knowledge and skills are not what is at issue.

With the decline of the Three Dynasties, the Kingly Way was extinguished and hegemonic methods flourished. After Confucius and Mencius passed away, the sage's learning became obscured and heterodox doctrines arose. Teachers no longer taught this, and students no longer studied this. The followers of the hegemons appropriated whatever resembled the former kings' ways, using it as an external pretense to serve their private selfish desires within. The world admired and followed them, and the Way of the sage was choked and blocked. People imitated one another, daily seeking doctrines of wealth and power, stratagems of deception and fraud, plans for attack and conquest—every kind of scheme for deceiving Heaven and defrauding people, seizing momentary advantage, and hunting for fame and profit. Those like Guan Zhong, Shang Yang, Su Qin, and Zhang Yi became innumerable.

After a long time, the fighting and plundering became unbearable in their calamity. People sank into barbarism and bestiality, and even hegemonic methods could no longer be practiced. The Confucian scholars of the age, deeply grieving, gathered and compiled the canonical writings and institutional regulations of the former sage-kings, patching and mending among the ashes. Their intention was indeed to restore the Way of the former kings. But the sage's learning was already remote, the traditions of hegemonic methods had accumulated deeply, and even the worthy and wise were not free from habitual influence. What they clarified and refined, seeking to proclaim and restore to the world, was barely sufficient to strengthen the hedges of the hegemons, while the gates and walls of the sage's learning could no longer be seen. Thus there arose textual exegesis, transmitted under the name of erudition; rote memorization, spoken of as breadth of learning; belles-lettres, flaunted as literary elegance. Such people sprang up in droves across the world—who knows how many schools—with ten thousand paths and a thousand trails, leaving no one knowing which way to turn.

The scholars of the world were like an audience at a theatrical spectacle: laughing, leaping, performing tricks, competing in novelty, vying in ingenuity, offering up amusement and contending in beauty—performers emerging on all four sides. Looking ahead and glancing behind, they could not keep up with it all. Their eyes were dazzled, their spirits confused. Day and night they wandered and lingered among these things like people who had lost their minds, no longer knowing where their own household and property had gone. The rulers of the age were likewise bewildered and confounded by these doctrines, spending their entire lives on useless empty formalities without knowing what they were about. Occasionally someone perceived the emptiness, error, fragmentation, and entanglement of it all, and resolutely roused himself to put things into practice. Yet at the utmost, such a person achieved nothing more than the enterprises of the Five Hegemons in wealth, power, and profit. The sage's learning grew daily more remote and obscure, while the habits of utilitarian pursuit sank ever lower. Although some were temporarily deluded by Buddhism and Daoism, in the end Buddhist and Daoist teachings could not overcome the utilitarian heart. Although some tried to find a middle ground among the various Confucian scholars, in the end the various scholars' discussions could not break through the utilitarian mentality.

By now, the poison of utilitarianism has soaked into people's very marrow and become their nature for nearly a thousand years. They compete in flaunting their knowledge, contend in leveraging their power, struggle over profit, and vie in displaying their skills and seeking their reputations. When they go forth to serve in office, those managing revenue wish to encroach upon military and penal affairs; those in charge of rites and music wish to meddle in personnel appointments. Those in prefectures and counties aspire to the heights of provincial posts; those in the censorate covet the importance of the grand councilors. If one cannot handle the affairs, one cannot hold the concurrent office. If one has not mastered the doctrines, one cannot claim the reputation. Breadth of memorization only serves to increase their arrogance. Abundance of knowledge only serves to advance their wickedness. Extensiveness of learning only serves to embolden their disputatiousness. Richness of literary composition only serves to ornament their falsity. What Gao Yao, Kui, Ji, and Qi could not combine in their persons, the beginning students of today all wish to master in doctrine and technique. Their nominal claims are never without the phrase 'I wish to jointly accomplish the affairs of the world,' but the true direction of their sincere hearts and actual intentions is that without such attainments they cannot advance their private interests and satisfy their desires.

Alas! With such accumulated habits, with such mentalities, and moreover studying such doctrines—is it any wonder that when they hear the teaching of our sage, they regard it as a useless appendage and a square peg in a round hole? That they should consider innate knowing insufficient, and the sage's learning useless—this is the inevitable outcome of such a situation! Alas! A scholar born in this age—how can he still seek the sage's learning? How can he still discuss the sage's learning? A scholar born in this age who wishes to learn—is it not toilsome and burdensome? Is it not constricting and perilous? Alas, how lamentable!

Yet fortunately, the Principle of Heaven in the human mind can never ultimately be extinguished. The luminosity of innate knowing is the same through ten thousand ages as in a single day. Those who hear my fundamental discussion of 'pulling up the root and blocking the source' will surely be moved to compassion, pained with sorrow, roused in indignation—surging forth like the breaking of a great river, with nothing that can hold them back. If not heroic persons who rise without waiting for external stimulus, on whom else can I place my hopes?

(This passage, from the eighth section beginning 'If the fundamental discussion of pulling up the root and blocking the source is not made clear to the world,' was once separately excerpted and published by Chen Longzheng under the title 'On Pulling Up the Root and Blocking the Source.' It is one of Wang Yangming's most celebrated essays, representing his ethical thought.)

Reply to Zhou Daotong

When the two students Wu and Zeng arrived, they conveyed in full Daotong's earnest devotion to the Way, which was most gratifying and comforting. Daotong may truly be called one who firmly believes and loves learning. Amid my illness, the gathering was brief, and I could not discuss in detail with the two students. Yet the two students also have their own aspirations and are willing to apply effort. Each time I see them, I perceive progress. On my part, I truly cannot claim to have been without shortcoming toward them in their coming from afar; on their part, they may also nearly be said to have not wasted their journey. At parting, I was asked to write a few words in this volume to convey my thoughts to Daotong. In my confusion and exhaustion, there is nothing worth saying, so I shall merely offer brief responses to several points from Daotong's letter. These are hastily written and far from detailed—the two students should be able to supplement them orally.

Your letter states: "In daily effort, the sole task is 'establishing one's resolve.' In recent times, constantly examining the Master's instructions through personal experience, this becomes ever more clear. Yet I cannot be separated from friends for even a moment. If I have friends to discuss and study with, this resolve becomes all the more vigorous, expansive, and full of vitality. If three to five days pass without such discussions among friends, I feel it becoming feeble. When encountering affairs, I become troubled, and at times I even forget. On days when no friends are available for discussion, I simply sit quietly, or read, or stroll about—in everything I see and everywhere I am, I take it all as nourishment for this resolve. I find my thoughts quite harmonious and at ease. Yet this still cannot compare with gathering with friends, when the spirit flows freely and there is far more vitality. For one who lives in isolation, cut off from the group—what other method is there to manage this?"

This passage sufficiently demonstrates the fruit of Daotong's daily effort. The general method of effort is roughly just like this. One need only continue without interruption; after it becomes fully mature, the quality of the experience will be different again. In general, the crucial essential of our learning is nothing but 'establishing one's resolve.' What you call the problems of 'being troubled' and 'forgetting' are simply because the resolve is not yet genuinely earnest. Consider a person infatuated with a beautiful woman—he never suffers from being troubled or forgetting; it is simply because he is genuinely earnest. One's own pain and itching, one must know for oneself; one must scratch and soothe for oneself. Once you know your own pain and itching, you cannot help but scratch and soothe. The Buddhists call this a 'skilful means'—one must adjust and calibrate it for oneself. Others cannot contribute their strength, and there is no other method that can be devised.

Your letter states: "Shang Cai once asked about 'what thought, what deliberation' in the world. Cheng Yi said: 'There is this principle, but the question is raised too early.' For the learner's effort, it is certainly a matter of 'there must be this undertaking, and do not forget.' Yet one must also recognize the bearing of 'what thought, what deliberation' and view both together as correct. If one does not recognize this bearing, there will be the problems of 'forcing' and 'helping to grow.' If one recognizes 'what thought, what deliberation' but forgets the effort of 'there must be this undertaking,' one may fall into emptiness. One must neither be attached to 'being' nor fall into 'nothingness.' Is this correct or not?"

Your discussion is not far off, but the insight is not yet complete. Shang Cai's question and Cheng Yi's answer merely represent their own intentions, and differ somewhat from the original purport of Confucius's Appended Remarks in the Book of Changes. The Appended Remarks' 'what thought, what deliberation' means that what one thinks and deliberates upon is solely the Principle of Heaven, with no other thought or deliberation—it does not mean there is no thought or deliberation at all. Therefore it says: 'They arrive at the same destination by different roads; they reach the same conclusion through a hundred deliberations. What thought, what deliberation is there in the world?' It says 'different roads' and 'a hundred deliberations'—how could this mean no thought or deliberation? The original substance of the mind is the Principle of Heaven. The Principle of Heaven is one and only one—what further thought or deliberation could there be? The Principle of Heaven is originally 'still and unmoving,' originally 'responsive and thereby penetrating all things.' The learner's effort, though it involves a thousand thoughts and ten thousand deliberations, is solely to restore the original substance and function, nothing more. It does not use private intent to arrange and contrive things. Therefore Cheng Hao said: 'The gentleman's learning—let him be vast and impartially public, and respond to things as they come.' If one uses private intent to arrange and contrive, that is 'using cleverness for selfish ends.' 'What thought, what deliberation' is precisely the effort itself. For the sage, it is natural and spontaneous. For the learner, it requires deliberate exertion. But Cheng Yi treated it as an effect or result, which is why he said 'raised too early.' His subsequent remark, 'Yet it is good for applying effort,' shows he had already sensed that his previous statement was not complete. Zhou Dunyi's discussion of 'ruling by stillness' also carries this meaning. Now Daotong's words are not without insight, but he still has not avoided treating these as two separate things.

Your letter states: "Whenever a learner has just understood how to apply effort, he should immediately recognize the bearing of the sage. For once one has recognized the sage's bearing and taken it as one's standard, one then applies effort on solid ground, and only then will one not go astray. This is the effort of becoming a sage. Is this correct or not?"

First recognizing the sage's bearing—this has indeed been said by people in the past. But it too lacks a proper starting point. The sage's bearing belongs to the sage—from what vantage point would I recognize it? If one does not genuinely examine it through one's own innate knowing, it is like using a scale with no markings to weigh things, or an unopened mirror to judge beauty and ugliness. This is truly what is called 'measuring the gentleman's heart with the petty person's belly.' How would one go about recognizing the sage's bearing? One's own innate knowing is originally the same as the sage's. If one genuinely examines one's own innate knowing clearly, then the sage's bearing is not in the sage but in me. Cheng Yi once said: 'If you stare at Yao and try to imitate his actions, without his degree of intelligence and wisdom, how could you match his every movement to propriety?' He also said: 'When the mind is penetrated by the Way, only then can one distinguish right from wrong.' Now let us ask: where is this 'penetration by the Way'? Where does this 'intelligence and wisdom' come from?

Your letter states: "Tempering oneself through actual affairs. Within a single day, whether there are affairs or not, one simply devotes oneself single-mindedly to cultivating the root source. If an affair comes or one is spontaneously moved, once the mind has some awareness, how can one say there is no affair? One simply concentrates the mind for a moment, generally perceiving what the principle of the matter requires, and handles it as if there were no affair—simply exhausting one's mind, that is all. Yet it happens that some affairs are handled well and others not so well. Why is that? Moreover, when affairs come in great number and must be dealt with in sequence, often one's strength is insufficient and one is overcome by them. Though one exerts oneself to the utmost to rally, one's spirit is already weakened. At such times, one cannot help but devote extra time to self-examination, preferring to leave affairs unfinished rather than failing to cultivate oneself. How about this?"

The effort you describe is, for someone at Daotong's level, also roughly how one should apply it. Yet it is not entirely free of inconsistency. In all of a person's learning throughout life, there is only this one matter. From youth to old age, from morning to evening, whether there are affairs or not, it is only doing this one thing—what is called 'there must be this undertaking.' If you say 'I would rather leave affairs unfinished than fail to cultivate myself,' that treats it as two separate things. 'There must be this undertaking; do not forget and do not help it grow.' When affairs and things come, simply exhaust the innate knowing of my mind in responding to them—this is what is called 'loyalty and reciprocity are not far from the Way.' Whenever one handles affairs with some handled well and others not, or encounters difficulties and loss of proper sequence, these are all because one is pulled by considerations of reputation, gain, and loss, unable to genuinely extend one's innate knowing. If one can genuinely extend one's innate knowing, then one will see that what formerly seemed good was not necessarily good, and what seemed not good may in fact have been a case of being pulled by reputation, gain, and loss, thereby injuring one's true knowing.

Your letter states: "Regarding the teaching of extending knowledge, when you further instructed me this spring, I already had some sense of how to apply effort and found it simpler and easier than before. But my humble thought is that when speaking of it to beginning students, one should still include the sense of 'investigation of things' to let them know where to begin. Originally 'extending knowledge' and 'investigation of things' go together. But for beginning students who do not yet know where to begin applying effort, one should still explain 'investigation of things'—only then will they understand what 'extending knowledge' means, and so forth."

'Investigation of things' is the effort of 'extending knowledge.' Once one understands 'extending knowledge,' one already understands 'investigation of things.' If one does not yet understand 'investigation of things,' then one has not truly understood the effort of 'extending knowledge' either. Recently I have written a letter to a friend discussing this quite thoroughly. I am sending you a copy now—read it carefully and you should see for yourself.

Your letter states: "The debate between Zhu Xi and Lu Xiangshan has not yet ceased among today's scholars. Whenever I speak to friends, I say: 'True learning has long been unclear. For now, there is no need to waste mental energy debating the rights and wrongs of Zhu and Lu. Simply follow the Master's two words—establishing one's resolve—to transform people. If a person can truly discern this resolve and determinedly commit to knowing this learning, then already the greater part is clear. The Zhu-Lu debate, even without being settled, will resolve itself for such a person.' I have also observed that among friends, when someone criticizes the Master's words, they immediately become agitated. In the past, the reason Zhu Xi and Lu Xiangshan bequeathed endless controversy to later generations was also that in both masters' efforts there was something not yet fully matured—clearly they too had the problem of becoming agitated. With Cheng Hao, this was not so. Consider his discussion with Wu Sheli about Wang Anshi's learning: 'Convey all of it to Anshi for me. If it does not benefit him, it will certainly benefit me.' What a composed bearing! I have also seen the Master quote this statement in a letter to someone. I wish all our friends could be like this. What do you think?"

This passage is extremely well argued—extremely well! I wish Daotong would share it broadly with our fellow seekers.
