Let each person discuss his own rights and wrongs, and not discuss the rights and wrongs of Zhu Xi and Lu Xiangshan. To slander a person with words—that slander is shallow. But if one cannot personally embody and practice the teaching, merely letting it pass in one ear and out the other, idly chattering away the days—that is slander with one's own person, and that slander is deep. All those in the world today who criticize me—if I can take their criticisms and turn them to good, they all become my whetstones and grindstones. Then there is nothing in my situation that is not a ground for vigilance, self-examination, and moral advancement. The ancients said: 'Those who attack my shortcomings are my teachers.' Can one hate one's teacher?

Your letter states: "Someone has quoted Cheng Yi's statement: 'Above the level of human life in its stillness, nothing can be said; once one speaks of the nature, it is already not the nature.' Why can nothing be said? Why is it already not the nature? Zhu Xi answered: 'Nothing can be said because there is not yet any nature to speak of. It is already not the nature because one cannot avoid the admixture of material endowment.' I cannot understand the statements of either master. Whenever I read to this point in the books, I am invariably confused. Please instruct me."

'What is produced is called the nature'—the word 'produced' is the word 'material force.' It is like saying 'material force is the nature.' If material force is the nature, then 'above the level of human life in its stillness, nothing can be said.' Once one says 'material force is the nature,' one has already fallen to one side and it is no longer the nature in its original source. Mencius's 'the nature is good' speaks from the original source. Yet the beginnings of the good nature must be seen in material force. Without material force, there would be nothing in which to see them. Compassion, shame, deference, and the sense of right and wrong—these are material force. When Cheng Yi said 'to discuss the nature without discussing material force is incomplete; to discuss material force without discussing the nature is unclear,' this was because learners each clung to one side, so he could only speak in this way. If one sees one's own nature clearly, then material force is the nature and the nature is material force—originally there is no separation of nature and material force.

Reply to Lu Yuanjing

Your letter states: "In beginning to apply effort, I find this mind never at rest. The deluded mind is certainly in motion, but the illuminating mind is also in motion. Since the mind is perpetually in motion, there is no moment of pause."

This is because you deliberately seek stillness, which is why you become all the more restless. The deluded mind is indeed in motion, but the illuminating mind is not in motion. When one constantly illuminates, there is constant motion and constant stillness—this is why Heaven and Earth endure without ceasing. The illuminating mind is indeed illumination, but the deluded mind is also illumination. When the thing is undivided, then the generation of things is unceasing. If there were a moment's pause, it would cease—and that would not be the learning of 'utmost sincerity without rest.'

Your letter states that "innate knowing also has a point of arising," and so forth.

Perhaps you did not hear this clearly. Innate knowing is the original substance of the mind—what was previously called 'constant illumination.' The original substance of the mind has no arising and no not-arising. Though deluded thoughts may stir, innate knowing is never absent. It is only that if a person does not know to preserve it, there are times when it may be let go. Though obscuration may reach its extreme, innate knowing is never not luminous. It is only that if a person does not know to examine it, there are times when it may be blocked. Though there are times of letting go, the substance has truly never been absent—one need only preserve it, that is all. Though there are times of being blocked, the substance has truly never ceased to be luminous—one need only examine it, that is all. If one says that innate knowing also has a point of arising, then it would sometimes not be present—and that would not be speaking of its original substance.

Your letter states: "Was the discussion the other day about 'refinement and singleness' the same as the effort of becoming a sage?"

The 'refined' of 'refinement and singleness' is spoken of in terms of principle. The 'refined' of 'vital essence and spirit' is spoken of in terms of material force. Principle is the orderly pattern of material force; material force is the functioning of principle. Without orderly pattern, there can be no functioning; without functioning, there is no way to see what is called orderly pattern. Refined leads to refinement; refined leads to clarity; refined leads to singleness; refined leads to spiritual; refined leads to sincere. Single leads to refined; single leads to clear; single leads to spiritual; single leads to sincere. Originally these are not two things. It is only that the theories of later Confucians and the theories of those who cultivate longevity have each become stuck on one side, which is why they cannot be mutually employed. The discussion of 'refinement and singleness' the other day, though it arose in connection with Yuanjing's concern for nourishing his vital spirit, is in fact not different from the effort of becoming a sage.

Your letter states: "The primal spirit, primal vital force, and primal essence must each have their places of storage and generation. Moreover, there is the true yin essence and the true yang vital force," and so forth.

Innate knowing is one. Spoken of in terms of its marvellous function, it is called spirit. Spoken of in terms of its flowing and circulating, it is called vital force. Spoken of in terms of its congealing and gathering, it is called essence. How can it be sought in terms of physical form and location? The true yin essence is the mother of the true yang vital force; the true yang vital force is the father of the true yin essence. Yin is rooted in yang, and yang is rooted in yin—they too are not two things. If my teaching of innate knowing is made clear, then all such matters can be understood without needing to be spoken of. Otherwise, matters like the 'three passes,' 'seven returns,' and 'nine reversions' that your letter mentions will present endless further doubts.

Furthermore—

Your letter states: "Innate knowing is the original substance of the mind, which is what is meant by 'the nature is good,' the 'centrality before the emotions are aroused,' the 'substance of stillness and unmovingness,' the 'vast impartiality.' Why then can ordinary people not achieve this, and why must they wait upon learning? If centrality, stillness, and impartiality already belong to the substance of the mind, then innate knowing is precisely that. But when I now examine my own mind, though my knowing is never not good, centrality, stillness, and vast impartiality are in fact not yet present. Does innate knowing then somehow transcend beyond substance and function?"

The nature is never not good; therefore knowing is never not innate. Innate knowing is itself the 'centrality before the emotions are aroused,' is itself 'vast impartiality,' is itself 'the substance of stillness and unmovingness'—what all people share equally. It is simply that one cannot avoid being obscured by material desires, and therefore must learn in order to remove the obscuration. Yet as for the original substance of innate knowing, learning cannot add to or diminish it by even a hair's breadth. That knowing is never not good yet centrality, stillness, and vast impartiality are not yet fully realized—this means that the obscuration has not yet been entirely removed and that preservation is not yet pure. The substance is the substance of innate knowing; the function is the function of innate knowing. How could there be anything 'transcending beyond substance and function'?

Your letter states: "Zhou Dunyi said 'ruling by stillness'; Cheng Yi said 'settled in motion, settled in stillness'; the Master says 'settledness is the original substance of the mind.' This stillness and settledness is certainly not what is meant by 'not seeing, not hearing' or 'without thought, without action.' It must mean constantly knowing, constantly preserving, constantly ruled by principle. But constant knowing, constant preserving, constantly ruled by principle—this is clearly motion, already aroused. How can it be called stillness? How can it be called the original substance? Is this stillness and settledness something that also penetrates through the motion and stillness of the mind?"

Principle is without motion. Constant knowing, constant preserving, constantly ruled by principle—this is precisely what is meant by 'not seeing, not hearing' and 'without thought, without action.' 'Not seeing, not hearing, without thought, without action' does not mean dried wood and dead ashes. When seeing, hearing, thinking, and acting are one with principle, and there has never been any seeing, hearing, thinking, or acting apart from it—this is motion that has never been motion. This is what is meant by 'settled in motion, settled in stillness' and 'substance and function sharing one source.'

Your letter states: "This substance of the mind before the emotions are aroused—does it exist before the arousal? Does it exist within the arousal as its ruler? Or is it without before and after, without inside and outside, as a unified whole? When we speak of the mind's motion and stillness, does this refer to having affairs and not having affairs? Does it refer to stillness-in-itself and responsiveness-in-penetration? Does it refer to following principle and following desire? If following principle is called stillness and following desire is called motion, then the statements 'within motion there is stillness, within stillness there is motion, motion reaches its extreme and becomes stillness, stillness reaches its extreme and becomes motion' would be incoherent. If having affairs and responsive-penetration is called motion, and not having affairs and stillness-in-itself is called stillness, then the statements 'motion without being moved, stillness without being still' would be incoherent. If one says the unaroused exists before the aroused, that stillness produces motion—this would mean utmost sincerity has cessation, that the sage has returning, which is also unacceptable. If one says the unaroused exists within the aroused, then I do not know: should both the unaroused and the aroused be characterized by stillness? Or is the unaroused stillness and the aroused motion? Or are both unaroused and aroused without motion and without stillness? Or do both have motion and stillness? Please instruct me."

The centrality before the emotions are aroused is innate knowing itself—without before and after, without inside and outside, a unified whole. Having affairs and not having affairs can be used to speak of motion and stillness, but innate knowing does not divide into having and not having affairs. Stillness-in-itself and responsive-penetration can be used to speak of motion and stillness, but innate knowing does not divide into stillness-in-itself and responsive-penetration. Motion and stillness are conditions encountered in time; the original substance of the mind fundamentally does not divide into motion and stillness. Principle is without motion; motion is desire. Following principle, though one responds to ten thousand changes, one has never been in motion. Following desire, though one's mind is withered and one's thought is single, one has never been still. 'Within motion there is stillness, within stillness there is motion'—what doubt is there? Having affairs and responsive-penetration can indeed be spoken of as motion, yet the stillness-in-itself has never been augmented. Not having affairs and stillness-in-itself can indeed be spoken of as stillness, yet the responsive-penetration has never been diminished. 'Motion without being moved, stillness without being still'—what doubt is there? Without before and after, without inside and outside, a unified whole—then the doubt about 'utmost sincerity having cessation' is resolved without needing explanation. The unaroused exists within the aroused, yet within the aroused there has never been a separate unaroused existing alongside. The aroused exists within the unaroused, yet within the unaroused there has never been a separate aroused existing within. This means there has never been no motion and stillness, yet motion and stillness cannot be used to divide it.

In reading the words of the ancients, one must use one's intention to trace back their purpose and grasp their overall meaning. If one must rigidly cling to the literal text, then 'not a single survivor remained' would mean that the Zhou truly had no people left. Zhou Dunyi's statement 'stillness reaches its extreme and becomes motion'—if not properly understood—is also not without problems. His meaning derives from 'The Supreme Ultimate moves and generates yang; it is still and generates yin.' The Supreme Ultimate's principle of ceaseless generation has its marvellous function that never ceases and its constant substance that never changes. Within this ceaseless generation, pointing to the marvellous function that never ceases and calling it motion, calling it the generation of yang—this does not mean that motion alone generates yang. Within this ceaseless generation, pointing to the constant substance that never changes and calling it stillness, calling it the generation of yin—this does not mean that stillness alone generates yin. If stillness alone generated yin and motion alone generated yang, then yin-yang and motion-stillness would each be rigidly separate things. Yin and yang are one vital force: one vital force bending and extending constitutes yin and yang. Motion and stillness are one principle: one principle hidden and manifest constitutes motion and stillness. Spring and summer can be called yang and motion, yet they are never without yin and stillness. Autumn and winter can be called yin and stillness, yet they are never without yang and motion. Spring and summer are this ceaseless activity; autumn and winter are this ceaseless activity—all can be called yang, called motion. Spring and summer are this constant substance; autumn and winter are this constant substance—all can be called yin, called stillness. From the cosmic epochs, eras, cycles, and ages, down to years, months, days, and hours, and further to moments, instants, and fractions—all are like this. This is what is meant by 'motion and stillness have no fixed beginning; yin and yang have no fixed starting point.' Those who know the Way comprehend it silently—it cannot be exhausted by words. If one merely clings to the text and sticks to the phrases, comparing and imitating by analogy, then as it is said: 'The mind is turned by the Lotus Sutra, rather than turning the Lotus Sutra.'

Your letter states: "When I try to examine my mind—in the stirring of joy, anger, anxiety, and fear, even when the agitation of vital force reaches its extreme, once my innate knowing becomes aware of it, they immediately dissolve and are blocked: sometimes checked at the beginning, sometimes controlled in the middle, sometimes regretted afterward. It seems as though innate knowing always dwells in a place of leisured detachment, serving as ruler, as if it did not participate in joy, anger, anxiety, and fear. Why is this?"

Knowing this, you can understand the centrality before emotions are aroused and the substance of stillness and unmovingness, and you can also understand the harmony of emotions aroused in due measure and the marvellous responsiveness that penetrates all things. However, to say that 'innate knowing always dwells in a place of leisured detachment'—this wording is still problematic. Though innate knowing does not become stuck in joy, anger, anxiety, and fear, nevertheless joy, anger, anxiety, and fear are also not outside of innate knowing.

Your letter states: "Yesterday the Master spoke of innate knowing as the illuminating mind. I humbly suggest that innate knowing is the original substance of the mind, while the illuminating mind is what a person uses in applying effort—the mind of vigilance and apprehension—which is akin to thinking. Yet you then identify vigilance and apprehension with innate knowing. Why is this?"

That which is capable of vigilance and apprehension—that is innate knowing.

Your letter states: "The Master also said: 'The illuminating mind is not motion.' Is this because following principle is called stillness? 'The deluded mind is also illumination.' Is this because innate knowing is never not present within it, never not luminous within it, and whatever in seeing, hearing, speaking, and moving does not transgress the proper measure is all the Principle of Heaven? Moreover, having called it the deluded mind, then from the perspective of the deluded mind it may be called illumination, but from the perspective of the illuminating mind it would be called delusion. How does delusion differ from cessation? Now to use the illumination of delusion to continue the unceasingness of utmost sincerity—this I do not yet understand. Please enlighten me further."

'The illuminating mind is not motion'—this is because it issues from the spontaneous luminous awareness of the original substance, and has never been set in motion. If there were motion, it would be delusion. 'The deluded mind is also illumination'—this is because the spontaneous luminous awareness of the original substance is never not present within it; it is simply that there is motion. Without motion, it is illumination. No-delusion-no-illumination does not mean taking delusion as illumination or illumination as delusion. If the illuminating mind is treated as illumination and the deluded mind as delusion, this is still having delusion and having illumination. Having delusion and having illumination means there is still duality. Duality means cessation. No-delusion-no-illumination means no-duality. No-duality means no-cessation.

Your letter states: "The essential of nurturing life is purifying the mind and having few desires. Once the mind is pure and desires are few, the work of becoming a sage is complete. Yet when desires are few, the mind becomes pure of itself. Purifying the mind does not mean abandoning human affairs to dwell in solitude seeking stillness. It means wishing to make this mind pure Heavenly Principle without a single hair's breadth of selfish human desire. Now if one wishes to do this work by eliminating selfish desires as they arise, the root of the disease always remains—it is extinguished in the east only to arise in the west. If one wishes to strip away and wash clean before the multitude of desires have sprouted, then there is no place to apply effort, and the mind is only made more impure. Moreover, to search out and root about for desires before they have sprouted in order to remove them is like leading a dog up into the hall and then chasing it out—this makes things even worse."

To insist on making this mind pure Heavenly Principle without a single hair's breadth of selfish human desire—this is indeed the work of becoming a sage. To insist on making this mind pure Heavenly Principle without a single hair's breadth of selfish human desire—this cannot be done without guarding against desires before they sprout and overcoming them at the moment of sprouting. Guarding before they sprout and overcoming at the moment of sprouting—this is precisely the effort of 'vigilance and apprehension' in the Doctrine of the Mean and 'extending knowledge and investigating things' in the Great Learning. Apart from this, there is no other effort.

As for what you call 'extinguished in the east only to arise in the west' and 'leading a dog up into the hall and then chasing it out'—these are the afflictions caused by self-interest, calculating gains and losses, and anticipatory purposefulness, not the problems of overcoming and cleansing. Now you say 'the essential of nurturing life is purifying the mind and having few desires'—just these two words 'nurturing life' are the very root of self-interest, calculating gains and losses, and anticipatory purposefulness. With this root of disease lurking within, it is no wonder you have the problems of 'extinguished in the east, arising in the west' and 'leading a dog up into the hall and then chasing it out.'

Your letter states: "When the Buddhists 'think neither of good nor of evil and recognize the original face,' their method differs from our Confucian effort of 'following things and investigating them.' If I were to apply the effort of extending knowledge at the moment of thinking neither of good nor of evil, I would already be involved in thinking of good. To desire that good and evil not be thought of, so that the innate knowing of the mind is pure and at ease of itself—this happens only at the moment of waking from sleep. This is precisely what Mencius meant by the 'night spirit.' But this state cannot last long. In the space of an instant, thoughts have already arisen. I do not know whether with prolonged effort, one can constantly be as when first waking from sleep and thoughts have not yet arisen. Now when I seek stillness, I become ever more restless; when I desire that no thoughts arise, thoughts arise all the more. What can be done so that earlier thoughts easily fade, later thoughts do not arise, innate knowing alone shines forth, and one roams with the Creator?"

'Think neither of good nor of evil, and recognize the original face'—this was the Buddhists' expedient method for those who had not yet recognized the original face. The 'original face' is what our Confucian school calls innate knowing. Now that one has already clearly recognized innate knowing, this way of speaking is no longer necessary.

'Following things and investigating them' is the effort of extending knowledge—it is what the Buddhists call 'constant wakefulness,' which is also just constantly preserving their original face. The general outline of the method and effort is roughly similar; it is only that the Buddhists have a heart of self-interest, which is why it becomes different. Now to desire that good and evil not be thought of, so that the innate knowing of the mind is pure and at ease of itself—this already contains the heart of self-interest, calculating gains and losses, and anticipatory purposefulness. This is why you have the problem of 'applying the effort of extending knowledge at the moment of thinking neither of good nor of evil, and already being involved in thinking of good.' When Mencius spoke of the 'night spirit,' he was merely pointing out to those who had lost their original good mind a place where that mind begins to stir, so they might cultivate it from there. Now that one already clearly knows innate knowing, and constantly applies the effort of extending knowledge, the talk of the 'night spirit' is no longer needed. This would be like catching the hare but then, instead of guarding the hare, continuing to guard the tree stump—the hare will again be lost. To desire stillness is to desire that no thoughts arise—this is precisely the disease of self-interest, calculating gains and losses, and anticipatory purposefulness. This is why thoughts arise all the more and one becomes ever more restless. Innate knowing is simply innate knowing—good and evil distinguish themselves naturally. What further good or evil is there to think about? The substance of innate knowing is originally still and at rest. Now you add the desire for stillness on top of it. It is originally alive and generative. Now you add the desire for no generation on top of it. Not only is this unlike the effort of extending knowledge in our Confucian school; even the Buddhists in their learning never had such anticipatory purposefulness. It is simply one thought of innate knowing, through and through, without beginning or end. This is precisely what is called 'earlier thoughts do not perish, later thoughts do not arise.' Now to desire that earlier thoughts easily perish and later thoughts not arise—this is what the Buddhists call cutting off the seed of the Buddha-nature, entering into the state of dried wood and dead ashes.

Your letter states: "The Buddhists also have the teaching of 'constantly holding up the thought.' Is this not similar to what Mencius calls 'there must be this undertaking,' and what the Master calls 'extending innate knowing'? Is it not the same as 'constantly wakeful, constantly remembering, constantly knowing, constantly preserving'? When this thought is being held up and affairs and things come, one's response to them must have its proper way. I only fear that the time of holding up this thought is brief and the time of letting it go is long—then the effort is interrupted. Moreover, the letting go of this thought mostly begins with the stirring of selfish desires and wayward impulses; only when one is suddenly startled awake does one hold it up again. In the interval between letting go and holding up, the confusion and clutter of the mind is mostly not self-perceived. Now I wish to be daily more refined and daily more luminous, constantly holding up without letting go—by what means can I do this? Is simply this constant holding-up-without-letting-go the complete effort? Or within this constant holding-up-without-letting-go, should one additionally add the effort of self-examination and overcoming? Though one says 'constantly hold up without letting go,' without adding the effort of vigilance, apprehension, and overcoming, I fear selfish desires will not be removed. If one adds the effort of vigilance, apprehension, and overcoming, that is already 'thinking of good,' and with regard to the 'original face' one is still short by one step. What should one do?"

Vigilance, apprehension, and overcoming—these are precisely the effort of constantly holding up without letting go. They are precisely 'there must be this undertaking.' How can there be two things? In this section of your question, the first part already explains itself clearly enough. But at the end you generate your own confusion and speak in a fragmented way, raising the doubt about 'the original face being one step short.' All of this is the disease of self-interest, calculating gains and losses, and anticipatory purposefulness. Remove this disease, and these doubts will naturally disappear.

Your letter states: "'Those of fine quality understand fully, and the dross is completely transformed.' What does it mean to 'understand fully'? How can the dross be 'completely transformed'?"

Innate knowing is originally self-luminous. Those whose material endowment is not fine have much dross and thick obscuration, making it difficult to become luminous. Those of fine quality originally have little dross and not much obscuration. With just a slight application of the effort of extending knowledge, this innate knowing becomes crystalline and transparent of itself. A small amount of dross is like snowflakes floating in hot water—how can it serve as an obstruction? This originally is not very difficult to understand. The reason Yuanjing raises doubts here is presumably because the single word 'understand' is not clear to him. There is also perhaps a slight impatience for quick results. I once discussed face-to-face the meaning of 'illuminating the good.' When one illuminates, one is sincere—this is not the shallow sense of 'illuminating the good' held by later Confucians.

Your letter states: "Are intelligence and wisdom truly matters of material endowment? Are humaneness, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom truly the nature? Are joy, anger, sorrow, and happiness truly the emotions? Are selfish desires and wayward impulses truly one thing or two? As for the talents of the ancients—men like Zhang Liang, Dong Zhongshu, Huang Xianzu, Zhuge Liang, Wang Tong, Han Qi, and Fan Zhongyan—their virtue and achievements were illustrious, all issuing from their innate knowing. Yet they cannot be said to have heard the Way. What exactly is the reason? If one says this is merely the fineness of their inborn quality, then those who are born knowing and act with natural ease—are they not superior to those who learn and then know, who act through strenuous effort? My humble opinion is that to say these men saw the Way only partially is acceptable, but to say they had no understanding at all, I fear, is an overreaction to the later Confucians' excessive veneration of memorization and textual exegesis. Is this correct or not?"

The nature is one and only one. Humaneness, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom are the nature's nature. Intelligence and wisdom are the nature's quality. Joy, anger, sorrow, and happiness are the nature's emotions. Selfish desires and wayward impulses are the nature's obscuration. Quality has degrees of clarity and turbidity; therefore emotions have excess and deficiency, and obscuration has shallowness and depth. Selfish desires and wayward impulses are one disease with two symptoms—not two things. Zhang Liang, Huang Xianzu, Zhuge Liang, Han Qi, and Fan Zhongyan all possessed fine natural endowments that naturally accorded in many ways with the subtleties of the Way. Though they cannot all be said to have known learning or heard the Way, they each had their own learning and did not deviate far from the Way. Had they been able to learn and know the Way, they would have been the equals of Yi Yin, Fu Yue, the Duke of Zhou, and Duke Shao. As for Wang Tong, he cannot be said to have had no knowledge of learning. Though his books were largely composed by his disciples and contain many points that are not quite right, his general outlines can still be seen. But the distance in time is too great, and there is no definite evidence to rely on, so one cannot determine from afar what level he reached. Innate knowing is the Way. Innate knowing in the human mind—not only sages and worthies, but even ordinary people possess it without exception. If there were no material desires pulling and obscuring it, one would simply follow the issuing and flowing of innate knowing—and there would be nothing that is not the Way. But in ordinary people, material desires pull and obscure it so much that they cannot follow their innate knowing. In men like these, whose natural endowments were already pure and clear, with few material desires to pull and obscure them, the issuing and flowing of their innate knowing was naturally abundant, naturally not far from the Way. What the learner learns is simply to follow this innate knowing. To call it 'knowing learning' simply means knowing that one should focus exclusively on following innate knowing. These men, though they did not know to focus exclusively on innate knowing for their effort, but perhaps wandered among many byways and were confused by shadows and echoes—this is why they were sometimes in accord and sometimes not, and not yet pure. Had they known this, they would have been sages. Later Confucians have often said that men like these were still merely using their material endowment, and were not free from 'acting without clear understanding, practicing without examination.' This is not an excessive judgment. But what later Confucians call 'clear understanding' and 'examination' is also confined by the narrowness of received learning, obscured by errors of accumulated habit, and dependent on imitation and analogy of shadows and traces—it is still not what the school of the sages calls 'clear understanding' and 'examination.' Then how can they, in their own benightedness, demand illumination from others? What is called 'born knowing and acting with natural ease'—the two words 'knowing' and 'acting' are also spoken in terms of applying effort. If we speak of the original substance of knowing and acting, then it is innate knowing and innate ability, and even those who learn through difficulty and act through strenuous effort can all be said to be born knowing and acting with natural ease. The two words 'knowing' and 'acting' deserve further careful examination.

Your letter states: "Formerly Zhou Dunyi always bade Cheng Hao to seek where Confucius and Yan Hui found their joy. May I ask: is this joy the same as the joy among the seven emotions, or not? If it is the same, then any ordinary person who gets what he wants can be joyful—why must one be a sage or worthy? If there is a separate true joy, then when the sage or worthy encounters great anxiety, great anger, great alarm, or great fear, is this joy still present? Moreover, the gentleman's mind always harbors vigilance and apprehension—this is a lifelong anxiety. How can there be joy? I have always been prone to melancholy and have never experienced the pleasure of true joy. Now I earnestly wish to seek it."

Joy is the original substance of the mind. Though it is not the same as the joy among the seven emotions, it is also not outside the joy of the seven emotions. Though the sage and worthy have a separate true joy, it is also something ordinary people equally possess. It is simply that ordinary people possess it without knowing it, and instead bring upon themselves all manner of anxiety and suffering, willfully adding confusion and abandonment. Even amid this anxiety, suffering, confusion, and abandonment, this joy has never ceased to be present. If but a single thought is awakened and illuminated, and one turns back to find sincerity within oneself, then it is right here. In every discussion with Yuanjing, there has been nothing but this meaning. Yet Yuanjing still asks 'by what means can one attain it'—this is still the error of 'riding the donkey while looking for the donkey.'

Your letter states: "The Great Learning says that when 'the mind has fondness, anger, anxiety, or fear, it cannot attain its correctness.' Cheng Yi also said that 'the sage's emotions accord with all things yet he has no emotions.' What is meant by 'having' has been illustrated in the Instructions for Practical Living with the analogy of malaria—this is extremely apt. But as for Cheng Yi's statement, it seems to mean that the sage's emotions do not arise in the mind but arise from things—what does this mean? Moreover, when affairs stimulate and emotions respond, then right and wrong can be directly investigated. But when affairs have not yet stimulated, to call it 'having' is to say it has not yet taken form; to call it 'not having' is to say the root of the disease lies in the space between having and not having. How then does one extend one's knowledge? If one studies to be without emotions, though the burden is lightened, one has departed from Confucianism and entered Buddhism. Is this acceptable?"

The sage's effort of extending knowledge is utmost sincerity without rest. The substance of his innate knowing is brilliant as a clear mirror, without the slightest particle of dust. Beauty and ugliness come before it, and each is reflected in its true form, yet the clear mirror has never retained any stain. This is what is called 'the emotions accord with all things yet he has no emotions.' 'Abiding nowhere yet giving rise to the mind'—the Buddhists have indeed said this, and it is not wrong. When the clear mirror responds to things, what is beautiful appears as beautiful, what is ugly as ugly—in one reflection all are true. This is the place of 'giving rise to the mind.' What is beautiful appears as beautiful, what is ugly as ugly—in one passing none are retained. This is the place of 'abiding nowhere.' The analogy of malaria, since you have already found it apt, should resolve the questions in this section. A person with malaria, even when the fever has not yet manifested, still has the root of disease present—so how can he, just because the fever has not manifested, neglect the effort of taking medicine and regulating his condition? If one must wait for the fever to manifest before taking medicine and regulating, it is already too late. The effort of extending knowledge has no interval between having affairs and not having affairs—so why distinguish between whether the disease has manifested or not? In general, Yuanjing's doubts, though they seem varied in front and behind, all arise from the affliction of self-interest, calculating gains and losses, and anticipatory purposefulness. Once this root is removed, all the doubts before and after will naturally melt away like ice and disperse like mist, without needing to be debated.

Postscript by Qian Dehong: When the Reply to Yuanjing was published, readers were all delighted that Cheng asked good questions and the Master gave good answers, and all felt they heard what they had never heard before. The Master said: "What Yuanjing asks is merely turning on the level of intellectual understanding. I had no choice but to follow each point and analyze it. If one truly trusts innate knowing and simply applies effort on innate knowing, though a thousand classics and ten thousand scriptures—none will fail to accord. Heterodox and deviant learning—a single examination exposes them all. Why must one dissect point by point like this? The Buddhists have the analogy of 'the dog chasing the clod.' If you see the clod and go after the person who threw it, you will get the person. If you see the clod and chase the clod, what will you get from the clod?" All the friends present heard this and were startled into awakening. This learning values turning inward—intellectual understanding alone cannot enter it.

Reply to Ouyang Chongyi

Chongyi wrote in his letter: "The Master said: 'The innate knowing of the moral nature does not derive from hearing and seeing. If one says that hearing much, selecting what is good and following it, and seeing much and noting it—this is exclusively seeking in the peripheral realm of hearing and seeing, and has already fallen to the second level.' I humbly think that although innate knowing does not arise from hearing and seeing, the learner's knowing has never failed to develop through hearing and seeing. To be stuck on hearing and seeing is certainly wrong, yet hearing and seeing are also the function of innate knowing. Now to say it 'has fallen to the second level' is perhaps directed at those who exclusively take hearing and seeing as their learning. If one extends one's innate knowing and seeks it through hearing and seeing, this too seems to be the effort of the unity of knowledge and action. What do you think?"

Innate knowing does not derive from hearing and seeing, yet hearing and seeing are nothing other than the function of innate knowing. Therefore innate knowing does not become stuck on hearing and seeing, yet also does not depart from hearing and seeing. Confucius said: 'Do I possess knowledge? I have no knowledge.' Beyond innate knowing, there is no other knowledge. Therefore 'extending innate knowing' is the great essential of learning—it is the sage's primary teaching to people. Now to say one 'exclusively seeks in the peripheral realm of hearing and seeing' is to lose this essential and already fall to the second level. Among our fellow seekers in recent times, there are already none who do not know the teaching of 'extending innate knowing.' Yet in their actual effort, many are still muddled—precisely because they lack this question. In general, the effort of learning requires only that the main direction and essential be correct. If the main direction and essential are focused exclusively on 'extending innate knowing,' then all broad hearing and seeing is nothing other than the effort of 'extending innate knowing.' For in daily use, all hearing, seeing, and social intercourse—though they involve a thousand threads and ten thousand ends—are nothing other than the issuing, flowing, and functioning of innate knowing. Apart from hearing, seeing, and social intercourse, there is no innate knowing to extend. Therefore it is all just one thing. But if one says 'extend one's innate knowing and seek it through hearing and seeing,' then the phrasing suggests two things. This differs somewhat from exclusively seeking in the peripheral realm of hearing and seeing, but in its failure to attain the purport of refinement and singleness, it is the same. 'Hearing much, selecting what is good and following it; seeing much and noting it'—since it says 'selecting' and 'noting,' innate knowing is not absent from within these activities. But the focus of intention is exclusively on hearing and seeing broadly in order to select and note—and this has already lost the essential. Chongyi's understanding of this matter should already be quite clear. Today's question is precisely aimed at illuminating this learning and is extremely beneficial among our fellow seekers. But if the wording is not yet perfectly clear, then the difference of a hair's breadth leads to a divergence of a thousand miles—one cannot fail to examine with precision.

Your letter states: "The Master said: 'The Appended Remarks says "what thought, what deliberation"—this means that what one thinks and deliberates is solely the Principle of Heaven, with no other thought or deliberation. It does not mean no thought or deliberation at all. The original substance of the mind is the Principle of Heaven—what is there that could be thought or deliberated about? The learner's effort, though it involves a thousand thoughts and ten thousand deliberations, is solely to restore the original substance. It is not using private intent to arrange and contrive—if one arranges and contrives, that is using cleverness for selfish ends.' The learner's errors mostly involve either sinking into emptiness and guarding stillness, or arranging and contriving with thought. In the xinren and renyin years I suffered from the former disease; recently I have been suffering from the latter. But thinking and contriving is also the function of innate knowing—how does it differ from the arranging of private intent? I fear I may be 'taking the thief for one's own son,' confused without realizing it."

'Thinking is called wisdom; wisdom leads to sagehood.' 'The function of the mind is thinking; through thinking one attains it.' How can thinking be dispensed with? Sinking into emptiness and guarding stillness, and arranging and contriving with thought—both are using cleverness for selfish ends. In losing innate knowing, they are the same. Innate knowing is where the Principle of Heaven shines forth in luminous spiritual awareness; therefore innate knowing is the Principle of Heaven. Thinking is the function of innate knowing. If it is the thinking that is the function of innate knowing, then what one thinks is nothing other than the Principle of Heaven. The thinking that is the function of innate knowing is naturally clear and simple. Innate knowing can also recognize it. If it is the thinking of private intent arranging and contriving, it is naturally confused and laborious. Innate knowing can also distinguish it. Whether thinking is right or wrong, orthodox or deviant—innate knowing is never not aware of it. The reason one 'takes the thief for one's own son' is precisely that the learning of extending knowledge is not clear, and one does not know to examine and recognize it through innate knowing.

Your letter further states: "The Master said: 'Learning throughout one's life is only this one thing. Whether there are affairs or not, it is only this one thing. If you say you would rather leave affairs unfinished than fail to add cultivation, that is splitting it into two things.' I humbly think: perceiving that one's energy is weak and insufficient to complete affairs—this is innate knowing. Preferring to leave affairs unfinished and adding rest and cultivation—this is extending knowledge. How is this two things? But if changes in affairs come that circumstances absolutely require one to handle, and though one's energy is weak, one can somewhat rally and manage—then 'maintaining one's resolve to command one's vital force' is acceptable. Yet one's speech and action ultimately lack force, and after completing the affair, exhaustion is extreme. Does this not come close to 'doing violence to one's vital force'? In weighing these considerations of gravity and urgency, innate knowing is certainly never unaware. But if pressed by circumstances, how can one attend to one's energy? If constrained by one's energy, how can one attend to circumstances? What should be done?"

The idea of 'preferring to leave affairs unfinished rather than failing to add cultivation'—for speaking with beginning students in this manner, it is not without benefit. But once you view it as two things, there is a problem. Mencius said 'there must be this undertaking'—the gentleman's learning throughout life is solely 'accumulating righteousness.' Righteousness means appropriateness; when the mind attains its appropriateness, that is called righteousness. To be able to extend innate knowing is for the mind to attain its appropriateness. Therefore 'accumulating righteousness' is simply extending innate knowing. The gentleman's responding to ten thousand changes—acting when action is appropriate, stopping when stopping is appropriate, living when living is appropriate, dying when dying is appropriate, adjusting and calibrating—all of this is nothing other than extending his innate knowing and seeking self-satisfaction, nothing more. Therefore 'the gentleman acts according to his station' and 'his thought does not go beyond his position.' Scheming about what is beyond one's strength and forcing what is beyond one's knowledge—none of these can be called extending innate knowing. But 'laboring one's sinews and bones, starving one's body and skin, impoverishing one's person, thwarting one's undertakings, stirring up one's mind and toughening one's nature to augment what one cannot yet do'—all of these are extending one's innate knowing. If one says 'preferring to leave affairs unfinished rather than failing to add cultivation,' this already comes from a utilitarian heart that calculates success and failure, advantage and disadvantage, with likes and dislikes mixed in. This treats completing affairs as one thing and cultivation as another separate thing. This already has the sense of 'internal versus external,' and is using cleverness for selfish ends. It is 'righteousness is external,' and already has the disease of 'not getting it from words, do not seek it in the mind; not getting it from the mind, do not seek it in the vital force.' It is no longer the effort of extending innate knowing to seek self-satisfaction. What you describe as 'rallying and managing, but being extremely exhausted after completing the affair,' and 'pressed by circumstances, constrained by energy'—all result from treating these as two things. In all the effort of learning, singleness means sincerity, duality means falsehood. All of this is because the intention of extending innate knowing lacks that single measure of genuine earnestness. The Great Learning says: 'Making one's intentions sincere is like hating a bad smell or loving a beautiful sight—this is called self-satisfaction.' Has there ever been a case of hating a bad smell or loving a beautiful sight that required rallying and exertion? Has there ever been a case of extreme exhaustion after completing such a response? Has there ever been a case of being pressed by circumstances or constrained by energy? From this one can see where the disease originates.

Your letter further states: "Human nature is full of a hundred kinds of deceit and cunning. If one meets it with unsuspecting trust, one is often deceived. But once one becomes alert, one has already fallen into suspicion and second-guessing. To second-guess deception is itself deception; to assume untrustworthiness is itself untrustworthy. Being deceived is also not being alert. Not second-guessing, not assuming untrustworthiness, yet being always the first to perceive—does this not come solely from innate knowing being crystalline and transparent? Yet in the space of the subtlest instant, cases of turning away from alertness and toward deception are many."

Not second-guessing, not assuming untrustworthiness, yet being the first to perceive—Confucius said this because people of his time focused exclusively on second-guessing deception and assuming untrustworthiness, thereby themselves falling into deception and untrustworthiness. There were also those who did not second-guess or assume untrustworthiness, but who, not knowing the effort of extending innate knowing, were often deceived. Hence he made this statement. It was not to teach people to keep this as their fixed mindset, exclusively desiring to be first in perceiving others' deception and untrustworthiness. To keep this as one's fixed mindset is precisely the concern of suspicious and petty people of later ages. Just this single thought already makes one unfit for the Way of Yao and Shun. Those who do not second-guess or assume untrustworthiness yet are deceived by others are still 'not without first being good.' They simply are not as admirable as those who extend their innate knowing and thereby naturally perceive first. Chongyi's statement that 'this comes solely from innate knowing being crystalline and transparent'—this already grasps the purport. Yet it is merely an intellectual insight, and I fear it is not yet practical. For innate knowing in the human mind, spanning ten thousand ages and filling the universe, is the same in all without exception. Without deliberation one knows; always easy so as to know what is dangerous. Without learning one is able; always simple so as to know what is obstructed. Prior to Heaven, Heaven does not deviate from it—even Heaven does not deviate, how much less people? How much less ghosts and spirits?

As for what you call 'turning away from alertness and toward deception'—this is because, though one does not second-guess others, one may not yet be free from self-deception. Though one does not assume others are untrustworthy, one may not yet be genuinely self-trusting. This is because one may still habitually seek to be the first to perceive, yet not always be self-perceiving. The habitual desire to be the first to perceive already drifts into second-guessing and assuming, which is sufficient to obscure one's own innate knowing. This is why the turning away from alertness and toward deception cannot be avoided. The gentleman's learning is for himself. He has never worried that others may deceive him—he simply never deceives his own innate knowing, that is all. He has never worried that others may not trust him—he simply trusts his own innate knowing, that is all. He has never sought to be the first to perceive others' deception and untrustworthiness—he simply attends to being constantly self-perceiving through his innate knowing, that is all. Therefore, when one does not deceive, then innate knowing has nothing false within it and is sincere; sincere, then luminous. When one is self-trusting, then innate knowing has nothing confused within it and is luminous; luminous, then sincere. Luminosity and sincerity generate each other—therefore innate knowing is constantly aware and constantly illuminating. Constantly aware and constantly illuminating, it is like a clear mirror hung high—things that come before it cannot conceal their beauty or ugliness. Why? When one does not deceive and is sincere, there is no room for deception within. Should there be any deception, one is immediately aware. When one is self-trusting and luminous, there is no room for untrustworthiness within. Should there be any untrustworthiness, one is immediately aware. This is what is called 'easy so as to know what is dangerous, simple so as to know what is obstructed.' It is what Zisi meant by 'utmost sincerity is like spiritual power—it can foreknow.' However, when Zisi says 'like spiritual power' and 'can foreknow,' he still speaks as if they were two things. This is because he is describing the effects for those who strive toward sincerity—he is still speaking for those who cannot yet naturally perceive first. If we speak in terms of utmost sincerity itself, then the marvellous function of utmost sincerity is itself called 'spiritual'—there is no need to say 'like spiritual power.' Utmost sincerity means 'knowing without knowing and having nothing one does not know'—there is no need to say 'can foreknow.'

Reply to Luo Zheng'an

I offer my respectful greetings. Yesterday you honored me with instruction regarding the Great Learning. As I was departing by boat in haste, I was unable to reply. This morning, with somewhat more leisure during the river journey, I took up your letter and read it again. Fearing that after arriving in Ganzhou, human affairs will again become pressing and confused, I first outline my brief response for your consideration.

Your letter states: "Seeing the Way is truly difficult, and embodying the Way is all the more difficult. The Way is indeed not easily illuminated, and learning indeed cannot go undiscussed. I fear one cannot rest content in one's present views and take them as the ultimate standard." How fortunate! How fortunate! How could I have the privilege of hearing such words? Would I dare to take my views as the ultimate standard and rest content in them? I am precisely thinking of seeking the Way throughout the world in order to discuss and illuminate it. Yet for several years now, those who have heard my teaching and ridiculed it are many; those who have reviled it are many; those who have dismissed it as unworthy of consideration or debate are many. But would any of them actually consent to instruct me? Would any consent to instruct me and then go back and forth patiently explaining, with heartfelt urgency, fearing they might not succeed in correcting me? If so, then among those in the world who love me, none has a mind so deep and devoted as yours. How could my gratitude be expressed? 'That virtue is not cultivated and learning is not discussed'—Confucius considered these his worries. Yet scholars of the age who can barely transmit and practice glosses and commentaries all consider themselves knowledgeable in learning, no longer feeling any need for what is called 'discussing learning.' How lamentable! The Way must be embodied before it can be seen—it is not that one first sees the Way and then adds the effort of embodying it. The Way must be studied before it becomes clear—it is not that outside of discussing learning there is some separate matter called 'illuminating the Way.' Yet among those in the world who discuss learning, there are two kinds: those who discuss it with body and mind, and those who discuss it with mouth and ears. To discuss with mouth and ears is to grope, estimate, and seek in shadows and echoes. To discuss with body and mind is to act with clear awareness, practice with thorough examination, truly possessing it in oneself. Understanding this, one can understand the learning of the school of Confucius.

Your letter says that I "restored the old text of the Great Learning because I hold that a person's learning should be sought only internally, and that Cheng Yi and Zhu Xi's doctrine of 'investigation of things' cannot avoid seeking externally—therefore I removed Zhu Xi's chapter divisions and deleted his supplementary commentary." This is not so. How can learning have an internal and external? The old text of the Great Learning is simply the original text transmitted in the school of Confucius. Zhu Xi suspected it had omissions and errors and corrected and supplemented it. In my view, it originally had no omissions or errors, and I merely follow the old text as it stands. My error lies in placing too much trust in Confucius, if anywhere—not in deliberately removing Zhu Xi's chapter divisions or deleting his commentary. Learning values what is attained in the mind. If I seek it in my mind and it is wrong, then even if the words come from Confucius, I dare not consider them right—how much less words from those who have not reached the level of Confucius? If I seek it in my mind and it is right, then even if the words come from an ordinary person, I dare not consider them wrong—how much less words from Confucius himself? Moreover, the old text has been transmitted for thousands of years. Now reading its language, it is already clear and comprehensible. Examining its method of effort, it is simple and accessible. On what basis does one determine that this section must belong there, that section must belong here, that this has such-and-such a lacuna, and that requires such-and-such a supplement—and thereby correct and supplement it? Is this not placing too much weight on contradicting Zhu Xi while taking too lightly the betrayal of Confucius?

Your letter states: "If learning truly need not draw upon external seeking, and one should only turn inward to self-reflection as one's task, then the four words 'rectifying the mind and making the intentions sincere' would already be fully sufficient. Why then must one at the very entrance be burdened with the additional step of 'investigation of things'?"

Indeed, indeed! If one speaks of the essential, the two words 'cultivating the self' would also suffice—why must one further speak of 'rectifying the mind'? 'Rectifying the mind' would also suffice—why must one further speak of 'making the intentions sincere'? 'Making the intentions sincere' would also suffice—why must one further speak of 'extending knowledge' and again of 'investigating things'? It is precisely because the effort is so detailed and meticulous, yet ultimately constitutes just one single thing—this is why it is called the learning of 'refinement and singleness.' This is precisely what must be thought through carefully. Principle has no internal and external; the nature has no internal and external; therefore learning has no internal and external. Lecturing, studying, and discussing have never been non-internal. Turning inward to self-reflection has never excluded the external. To say that learning must draw upon external seeking is to regard one's own nature as having an outside—this is 'righteousness is external,' the way of those who use cleverness. To say that turning inward to self-reflection is seeking internally is to regard one's own nature as having an inside—this is having a fixed self, the way of selfish people. Both fail to understand that the nature has no internal or external. Therefore it says: 'Refining righteous principle to enter the spiritual realm is for the purpose of practical application. Benefiting through practical application and settling the self is for the purpose of exalting virtue.' 'It is the virtue of the nature—uniting internal and external as one Way.' From this one can understand the learning of 'investigation of things.' 'Investigation of things' is the actual starting point of effort in the Great Learning, from beginning to end, from the first student to the sage—it is only this one effort. It is not merely a single step at the entrance. 'Rectifying the mind,' 'making the intentions sincere,' 'extending knowledge,' 'investigating things'—all of these serve to 'cultivate the self.' 'Investigating things' is the place where effort is applied that can be seen daily. Therefore 'investigating things' means investigating the things of one's mind, investigating the things of one's intentions, investigating the things of one's knowledge. 'Rectifying the mind' means rectifying the mind of one's things. 'Making the intentions sincere' means making sincere the intentions of one's things. 'Extending knowledge' means extending the knowledge of one's things. How can there be any division of internal and external, this and that? Principle is one and only one. Spoken of in terms of its congealing and gathering, it is called the 'nature.' Spoken of in terms of the master of its congealing, it is called the 'mind.' Spoken of in terms of the activation of its mastery, it is called the 'intention.' Spoken of in terms of the luminous awareness of its activation, it is called 'knowledge.' Spoken of in terms of the responsiveness of its luminous awareness, it is called 'things.' Therefore, in terms of things we say 'investigate'; in terms of knowledge we say 'extend'; in terms of intentions we say 'make sincere'; in terms of the mind we say 'rectify.' Rectifying—rectifying this. Making sincere—making sincere this. Extending—extending this. Investigating—investigating this. All of these are what is called 'exhausting principle to fully realize the nature.' Under Heaven there is no principle outside the nature, no things outside the nature. The obscurity of learning is entirely because the Confucians of the age regard principle as external and things as external, not knowing that the doctrine of 'righteousness is external' was already refuted by Mencius. Yet they have unwittingly fallen into the same trap. Is this not because there is something that seems right but is difficult to discern? One cannot fail to examine it carefully!

The reason you raise doubts about the doctrine of 'investigation of things' is necessarily because you think it affirms the internal and denies the external; that it exclusively devotes itself to introspection and self-reflection while abandoning the effort of lecturing, studying, and discussing; that it focuses single-mindedly on the essentials of the great principles and root source while neglecting the details of branches and particulars; that it sinks into the one-sidedness of withered emptiness and dead stillness without exhausting the changes of the principles of things and human affairs. If this were truly so, it would not merely offend against the school of the sages and offend against Zhu Xi—it would be heterodox doctrine deceiving the people, betraying the Way and disrupting the correct, which anyone would be justified in condemning. How much more so a person of your rectitude! If this were truly so, anyone in the world with a modest understanding of commentaries who has heard the general discussions of earlier worthies would know it is wrong—how much more so a person of your brilliance! In all that I mean by 'investigation of things,' Zhu Xi's nine methods are all encompassed and subsumed within it. The only difference is that there is a governing essential, and the manner of application differs—this is precisely what is called the difference of a hair's breadth. Yet the difference of a hair's breadth leads to an error of a thousand miles. The divergence truly begins here and cannot go undistinguished.

When Mencius refuted Yang Zhu and Mo Di, he went so far as to say they were 'without father and without ruler.' These two men were also worthies of their time. Had they lived in the same era as Mencius, he might well have considered them worthy. Mo Di's universal love was practicing humaneness to excess; Yang Zhu's being for oneself was practicing righteousness to excess. Their doctrines—how could they have been extreme enough to subvert principle and disorder the norms, sufficient to dazzle the world? Yet the ultimate consequences of their influence, in Mencius's view, reduced people to the level of beasts and barbarians. This is what is meant by 'killing the world and later generations through learning.' Now the learning of our present age—should it be called learning humaneness to excess? Learning righteousness to excess? Or learning neither humaneness nor righteousness to excess? I do not know how it compares to floods and fierce beasts. Mencius said: 'Am I fond of disputing? I have no choice.' When the doctrines of Yang Zhu and Mo Di filled the world, in Mencius's time, the world's reverence for Yang and Mo was surely no less than today's veneration of Zhu Xi's teachings. Yet Mencius alone raised his voice ceaselessly in their midst. Alas, how pitiable! Han Yu said: 'The harm of Buddhism and Daoism is greater than that of Yang and Mo.' Han Yu's worthiness did not match Mencius's. Mencius could not save things before the decline; Han Yu wished to restore things after the decline—he did not measure his own strength, and moreover saw his own person endangered with no one to rescue him, unto death. Alas! As for someone like myself—I measure my strength even less, and truly see my person endangered with no one to rescue me, unto death. To cry out alone amid the general merriment; to be seized with alarm while the whole world blithely pursues its course—if this is not madness and loss of mind, then there must truly be a great suffering hidden within that only one of the utmost humaneness under Heaven can perceive.

As for composing the Record of Zhu Xi's Final Conclusions, this too was something I could not avoid. The relative dating of early and late years does indeed have points not yet fully researched. Though they may not all come from his late years, many certainly do. The main intention was to mediate and harmonize, taking the illumination of this learning as the priority. Throughout my life I have revered Zhu Xi's teachings like divine pronouncements and oracle shells. To suddenly turn against him—my heart truly could not bear it. Therefore I felt compelled to compose this work. 'Those who understand me will say my heart is grieved; those who do not understand will say what am I seeking?' Not daring to contradict Zhu Xi—that was my true heart. Being compelled to contradict him—the Way simply requires it. 'If one is not straightforward, the Way cannot be seen.'

What you say about my 'certainly differing from Zhu Xi'—would I dare deceive my own heart? The Way is the public Way of all under Heaven. Learning is the public learning of all under Heaven. It is not something Zhu Xi can make his private possession, nor something Confucius can make his private possession. It is the public possession of all under Heaven—one simply speaks of it publicly, that is all. Therefore, if something is said and it is right, though it differs from my own view, it benefits me. If something is said and it is wrong, though it agrees with my own view, it actually harms me. What benefits me, I will surely welcome. What harms me, I will surely dislike. If so, then what I now argue, though it may differ from Zhu Xi, may not be unwelcome to him. 'The gentleman's errors are like eclipses of the sun and moon—when he corrects them, all people look up to him.' But 'the petty person's errors are always glossed over.' Though I am unworthy, I would certainly not dare to serve Zhu Xi with the petty person's heart.

What you have instructed me in your letter, going back and forth for several hundred words, all proceeds from not yet fully understanding my doctrine of 'investigation of things.' If my doctrine were once made clear, then these several hundred words would all resolve themselves without needing debate and be free of obstruction. Therefore I dare not go on at length, adding trivial annoyance. However, without face-to-face oral explanation, my doctrine can certainly not be made entirely clear through brush and paper.

Alas! The lengths to which you have gone to guide and enlighten me—they may truly be called earnest and thorough. Among those who love me, is there anyone who compares with you? Though I am very dull and lowly, how could I not be deeply moved and gratefully admiring? Yet I dare not hastily abandon what my heart holds to be genuinely so and merely accept your words—precisely because I dare not fail your deep love, and also think to repay it. When autumn ends and I return east, I will certainly seek a meeting to conclude my inquiries. I earnestly hope you will continue to instruct me to the end.

Reply to Nie Wenwei

This spring you took the trouble to detour far from your path to visit me, tirelessly discussing and verifying—how can I adequately express my feelings? I had already arranged for two or three fellow seekers to find a quieter place, hoping to detain you for ten days or so and humbly offer my views in pursuit of the benefit of mutual polishing. But your official schedule and worldly obligations made this impossible. Parting from you, I was extremely disappointed, as if I had lost something. Then suddenly I received your gracious letter of over a thousand words. Reading it brought me no less than cleansing comfort. The excessive praise therein comes from your generous heart of encouragement. But your admonitions are genuine and earnest, desiring to lead me into the realm of sages and worthies. Through Chongyi you also conveyed your unflagging devotion. Without deep friendship and sincere love, how could this be possible? I am both grateful and ashamed, and moreover fear I am unequal to such regard. Yet how dare I not whip and urge myself, and merely offer gratitude, shame, and modest disclaimers?

Your statement that 'Si, Meng, Zhou, and Cheng did not intentionally encounter one another across a thousand years. Rather than being fully believed by the whole world, it is better to be truly believed by one person. The Way exists of itself; learning also exists of itself. The whole world believing it does not make it more; one person believing it does not make it less'—this is indeed the mind of the gentleman who 'is not seen by others yet is not troubled.' How could the petty and trivial people of the world have knowledge sufficient to reach this? Yet in my own feelings, there is a great compulsion that cannot be helped—it is not a calculation of whether others believe or not.

Human beings are the mind of Heaven and Earth. Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things are originally one body with us. The suffering and misery of the common people—which of these is not a pain cutting into my own body? To be unaware of one's own body's pain is to lack the mind that distinguishes right and wrong. The mind that distinguishes right and wrong knows without deliberation and is capable without learning—this is what is called 'innate knowing.' Innate knowing in the human mind admits no distinction between sage and fool—it is the same throughout the world across all ages. If the gentlemen of the world would simply devote themselves to their innate knowing, then they would naturally be able to be impartial about right and wrong, share likes and dislikes, regard others as themselves, regard the state as their own household, and take Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things as one body. Seeking a world without good governance would be impossible. The reason the ancients could see good as if it came from themselves, see evil as if it entered themselves, regard the people's hunger and drowning as their own hunger and drowning, and feel that if a single person lacked proper livelihood it was as if they themselves had pushed that person into a ditch—this was not done deliberately to win the world's trust. They simply devoted themselves to extending their innate knowing and seeking self-satisfaction, nothing more. The sagely virtue of Yao, Shun, and the Three Kings—when they spoke, the people all believed them, because they extended their innate knowing in their speech. When they acted, the people were all pleased, because they extended their innate knowing in their actions. Therefore their people lived in joyful harmony—even being punished, they harbored no resentment; even being benefited, they did not boast of it. This reached even to the distant barbarians, and all who had blood and breath revered and loved them—because their innate knowing was the same. Alas! The sage's governance of the world—how simple and easy it is!

In later ages, the learning of innate knowing became unclear. The people of the world used their private cleverness to compete and jostle with one another. Each person had his own mind, and petty, devious, and base views, and cunning, deceitful, and sinister methods became beyond description. Outwardly they borrowed the name of humaneness and righteousness, while inwardly they pursued their self-interested reality. They used specious words to flatter the vulgar and affected conduct to fish for praise. They concealed others' virtues and claimed them as their own merits; they exposed others' private faults and stole credit for being upright. They conquered one another through anger yet still called it pursuing righteousness; they toppled one another through treachery yet still called it hating evil. They envied the worthy and capable yet still considered themselves impartial about right and wrong; they indulged their passions and desires yet still considered themselves sharing the common likes and dislikes. They attacked and preyed upon one another—even within their own families, among flesh and blood, they could not avoid the mentality of winning and losing, the barriers of us and them. How much less could they view the vastness of the world and the multitude of peoples and things as one body? It is no wonder that disorder and calamity followed one upon another without end.

I have been fortunate, through Heaven's grace, to have chanced upon some insight into the learning of innate knowing. I believe it is only through this that the world can be brought to order. Therefore, whenever I think of the people's drowning in suffering, my heart aches with pain. Forgetting my own unworthiness, I think to rescue them through this teaching—without even measuring my own capacity. The people of the world, seeing me like this, have joined in mocking and denouncing me, taking me for a madman who has lost his mind. Alas! What is there to worry about in this? I am in the midst of pain that cuts to the bone—do I have leisure to care about others' mockery? Consider: if a person sees his father, son, or brother fall and drown in a deep abyss, he will cry out and crawl forward, barefoot and stumbling, grasping at cliff walls to descend and rescue them. The gentlemen who observe this stand by, bowing politely and chatting with smiles, thinking that this person has abandoned his propriety and attire to cry out and stumble about in such a manner—he must be a madman who has lost his mind. To bow politely and chat smilingly beside a drowning person without knowing to rescue him—only a stranger with no familial bond of flesh and blood could do this. Yet even such a person would be called one without compassion—not human. But if it is one's own father, son, or brother whom one loves, then there is none who would not be pained to the heart and anguished, running madly and exhausting every breath, crawling to the rescue. The danger of drowning itself is not a concern—how much less the censure of being a madman! And how much less whether others believe in one or not! Alas! Though the people of today call me a madman who has lost his mind, there is nothing unacceptable in this. The minds of all people under Heaven are my own mind. If there are still madmen among the people of the world, how can I not also be mad? If there are still those who have lost their minds, how can I not also have lost my mind?

In former times, when Confucius was alive, there were those who accused him of flattery, those who mocked him as glib, those who disparaged him as not yet worthy, those who scorned him as ignorant of ritual, those who insulted him as 'the Qiu from the east end of the village,' those who were jealous and obstructed him, and those who hated him and wished to kill him. The morning gatekeeper and the man carrying the basket—both worthies of their time—said: 'Is this not the one who knows it cannot be done yet keeps doing it?' and 'How stubborn and petty! If no one understands you, just stop.' Even Zilu, who was among those who had 'ascended the hall,' could not avoid doubting what the Master saw and being displeased at where the Master wished to go, even considering him impractical. If so, were those who did not believe in the Master limited to merely two or three in ten? Yet the Master hurried about anxiously as if searching for a lost child on the road, never warming his seat. Was this merely to seek others' understanding and belief? It was because his humaneness of forming one body with Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things was so painfully urgent that even had he wished to stop, there was something that would not let him. Therefore his words: 'If I am not a follower of mankind, then what am I?' 'To keep oneself pure while bringing disorder to the great relationships.' 'How resolute! But in the end it is difficult.' Alas! Without being one who truly forms one body with Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things, who could understand the Master's heart? As for 'living in obscurity without resentment, knowing destiny and finding joy in Heaven'—this means there is nowhere one enters without being at ease, and parallel paths do not conflict with each other.

As for my unworthy self, how would I dare take the Way of the Master as my own responsibility? Yet my heart has already come to feel something of the pain as if it were in my own body. Therefore I look about in all four directions, hoping to find those who can help me, together to discuss and treat the disease. If I could truly obtain heroic and like-minded men to support and assist one another, jointly illuminating the learning of innate knowing throughout the world, enabling all people to know to extend their own innate knowing, to nurture and sustain one another in peace, to remove the obscuration of self-interest, to wash away the habits of slander, jealousy, and competitive anger, and thereby reach the Great Unity—then my own mad disease would surely be cured at once, and I would ultimately escape the affliction of having lost my mind. Would that not be joyous?

Alas! If one truly seeks heroic and like-minded men throughout the world, to whom can one look if not to our Wenwei? With Wenwei's talent and aspiration, he is truly capable of rescuing the world from drowning. Now that you also know the means for this lies within yourself and needs no external seeking, if you follow this and fill it out, it will be like breaking through a dike to pour into the sea—who can hold it back? Wenwei's statement that 'one person believing it does not make it less'—could he modestly defer this to anyone else?

Kuaiji has always been renowned as a region of mountains and waters. Deep forests and long valleys present themselves at every casual step. Whether in cold or heat, in darkness or light, no time is unsuitable. Dwelling in peace and eating one's fill, free from the dust and clamor, with good friends gathering from all sides and the Way and righteousness renewed daily—how leisurely and at ease! Between Heaven and Earth, could there be any joy greater than this? Confucius said: 'I do not resent Heaven; I do not blame others. I study what is below and comprehend what is above.' My two or three fellow seekers and I are about to devote ourselves to these words—what leisure have we for external admiration? It is only the pain that cuts to the skin from which I cannot remain unmoved—hence these repeated words.

Suffering from a cough and the summer's poison, I have been extremely lazy about correspondence. Your generous messenger came from afar and was kept waiting for over a month. As I take up my brush at the point of departure, I find myself unawares filling page after page. For between those who know each other so deeply, though I have already gone on at such length, I still feel there is something I have not been able to express fully.

II
