Receiving your letter and seeing the rapid progress of your recent learning, my joy and gratification are beyond words. Reading it over carefully several times, though there are one or two points not yet perfectly clear, this is simply because the effort of extending innate knowing is not yet fully mature. When it reaches full maturity, these will naturally disappear. It is like driving a carriage: once you are already traveling on the broad highway, if at times there are swerves and curves, this is because the horses' temperament is not yet trained and the reins are not yet even. But you are already on the broad highway and will certainly not be led astray into side paths and byways. Among our fellow seekers throughout the realm in recent times, I have seldom seen anyone who has reached this level. My joy and gratification are beyond words—what good fortune for the Way! My poor body has long suffered from coughs and intolerance of heat. Now having entered the hot southern regions, it has flared up again greatly. His Majesty in his sagely clarity sees through everything, and the responsibilities entrusted to me are weighty. I dare not hastily decline. Local affairs and military duties are complex and pressing, and I attend to them all while ill. Now fortunately things have been pacified. I have already submitted a memorial requesting leave to convalesce. If I can retire to the woods and find some coolness, perhaps I may recover. As the messenger returns, I write hastily while propped on my pillow, unable to express all my longing. Please also forward the enclosed note to Weijun.

Regarding the inquiries in your letter, I hastily reply to one or two points. In recent years, those who come to study in the mountains have often said that the effort of 'do not forget, do not help grow' is very difficult. When I ask them about it, they say: 'The moment you pay attention, that is helping. The moment you stop paying attention, that is forgetting. So it is very difficult.' I then ask them: 'Forgetting—forgetting what? Helping—helping what?' They fall silent, unable to answer, and only then do they ask. I then explain: In my teaching here, I speak only of 'there must be this undertaking'—I do not speak of 'do not forget, do not help grow.' 'There must be this undertaking' simply means constantly going about 'accumulating righteousness.' If you constantly apply the effort of 'there must be this undertaking,' and sometimes it is interrupted—that is forgetting, and then you need 'do not forget.' If you constantly apply the effort of 'there must be this undertaking,' and sometimes you seek quick results—that is helping, and then you need 'do not help.' The entire effort is applied on 'there must be this undertaking.' 'Do not forget, do not help' merely serve as reminders and alerts within that effort. If the effort is originally uninterrupted, there is no further need to speak of 'do not forget.' If it originally does not seek quick results, there is no further need to speak of 'do not help.' How clear and simple this effort is! How free and at ease! Yet now, instead of applying effort on 'there must be this undertaking,' people suspend themselves in empty air clinging to 'do not forget, do not help.' This is like lighting a fire to cook rice when there is no water in the pot and no rice—you are just adding firewood and stoking the flame. What do you suppose will be cooked? I fear the fire will not even be properly regulated before the pot has already cracked. Those who recently devote themselves exclusively to the effort of 'do not forget, do not help' have precisely this problem. All day long they work at 'do not forget' in empty suspension, and then work at 'do not help' in empty suspension. Vast and drifting, they have absolutely no concrete place to begin. In the end, their effort amounts only to sinking into emptiness and guarding stillness, producing a dull and insensible person. The moment any small affair arises, they are immediately entangled and confused, unable to manage or govern it. These are all men of aspiration, yet they have been made to labor and struggle, fettered and burdened, wasting an entire lifetime—all because of the error of misguided doctrine. How pitiable!

'There must be this undertaking' is simply 'accumulating righteousness.' 'Accumulating righteousness' is simply 'extending innate knowing.' Speaking of 'accumulating righteousness,' one cannot immediately see the main point. Speaking of 'extending innate knowing,' one immediately has solid ground where effort can be applied. This is why I speak exclusively of 'extending innate knowing.' Extending one's innate knowing moment by moment in the midst of affairs—this is 'investigation of things.' Genuinely extending innate knowing—this is 'making the intentions sincere.' Genuinely extending one's innate knowing without a single hair's breadth of arbitrariness, insistence, rigidity, or egoism—this is 'rectifying the mind.' Genuinely 'extending innate knowing'—then there is naturally no problem of 'forgetting.' Without a single hair's breadth of arbitrariness, insistence, rigidity, or egoism—then there is naturally no problem of 'helping.' Therefore, speaking of 'investigation, extension, sincerity, and rectification,' one need not further speak of 'forgetting and helping.' When Mencius spoke of 'forgetting' and 'helping,' he was prescribing medicine for Gaozi's specific disease. Gaozi forcibly controlled his mind—this was the disease of 'helping.' Gaozi's helping to grow was also because he regarded righteousness as external, not knowing to 'accumulate righteousness' within his own mind, not applying effort on 'there must be this undertaking.' If moment by moment one 'accumulates righteousness' within one's own mind, then the substance of innate knowing is transparently clear. Naturally, right and wrong are distinguished without the slightest thing escaping notice. Then how could there be the error of 'not getting it from words, do not seek it in the mind; not getting it from the mind, do not seek it in the vital force'? Mencius's teaching of 'accumulating righteousness and nourishing the vital force' is indeed of great benefit to later learners. Yet it too was a prescription for a specific disease, stated in broad terms. It is not as refined, single-minded, and simple as the Great Learning's effort of 'investigation, extension, sincerity, and rectification,' which is thorough from top to bottom and without deficiency through ten thousand generations.

When sages and worthies discuss learning, they mostly adapt to the time and the situation. Though their words seem to differ from person to person, the essential method and main point are in perfect accord, like matching tallies. This is because between Heaven and Earth, there is originally only this nature, only this principle, only this innate knowing, only this one thing. Therefore, in discussing effort wherever the ancients discussed learning, one need not blend and combine different formulations—they will naturally accord and penetrate one another without exception. The moment one must blend and combine to make them coherent, it means one's own effort is not yet thoroughly clear. Recently there are those who say the effort of 'accumulating righteousness' must be blended with 'extending innate knowing' before it is complete. This means the effort of 'accumulating righteousness' is not yet thoroughly understood. If the effort of 'accumulating righteousness' is not yet thoroughly understood, it only serves as a burden to 'extending innate knowing.' Those who say the effort of 'extending innate knowing' must be blended with 'do not forget, do not help' before it is clear—this means the effort of 'extending innate knowing' is not yet thoroughly understood. If the effort of 'extending innate knowing' is not yet thoroughly understood, it only serves as a burden to 'do not forget, do not help.' All such cases involve interpreting and forcing connections at the level of textual meaning, seeking confused fusion and forced coherence, without ever having examined things in one's own actual effort. This is why the more refined the discussion, the more remote it becomes from the reality.

Wenwei's discussion, in its grasp of the great root and the universal Way, is already flowing and without doubt. As for the teachings on 'extending knowledge,' 'exhausting principle,' and 'forgetting and helping'—there are places where he still blends and combines. But this is what I have called swerving and curving while on the broad highway. When the effort is fully mature, these will naturally dissolve.

Wenwei says that seeking the teaching of 'extending knowledge' in the context of serving parents and following elders, he feels there is something to hold to and follow. This passage best shows the genuine and solid effort of recent times. But while using this for oneself is fine and provides real power, if one then makes it a fixed doctrine to teach others, there is the danger of 'the medicine itself causing the disease.' This too cannot go undiscussed.

Innate knowing is simply the one place where the Principle of Heaven naturally shines forth in luminous awareness—simply one thing: genuine sincerity and compassionate concern. This is its original substance. Therefore, extending this genuine sincerity and compassionate concern of innate knowing in serving one's parents is filial piety. Extending this genuine sincerity and compassionate concern of innate knowing in following one's elder brother is brotherly respect. Extending this genuine sincerity and compassionate concern of innate knowing in serving one's ruler is loyalty. It is simply one innate knowing, one genuine sincerity and compassionate concern. If the innate knowing of following one's elder brother cannot extend its genuine sincerity and compassionate concern, then the innate knowing of serving one's parents also cannot extend its genuine sincerity and compassionate concern. If the innate knowing of serving one's ruler cannot extend its genuine sincerity and compassionate concern, then the innate knowing of following one's elder brother also cannot extend its genuine sincerity and compassionate concern. Therefore, to have extended the innate knowing of serving one's ruler is to have extended the innate knowing of following one's elder brother. To have extended the innate knowing of following one's elder brother is to have extended the innate knowing of serving one's parents. It is not that the innate knowing of serving one's ruler cannot be extended, so one must go back to the innate knowing of serving one's parents to expand it outward. To do so would be to detach from the root source and fix upon the branches. Innate knowing is simply one. Wherever it manifests and flows, it is fully present in that moment—without coming or going, without needing to borrow from elsewhere. Yet in its manifestation and flowing, there are naturally degrees of weight and thickness that cannot be altered by even a hair's breadth. This is what is called 'the natural Mean inherent in things.' Though there are degrees of weight and thickness that cannot be altered by a hair, the thickness is still one single thing. Though it is one single thing, within it the degrees of weight and thickness still cannot be altered by a hair. If it could be altered, if it needed to borrow—then it would no longer be the original substance of genuine sincerity and compassionate concern. This marvellous function of innate knowing—having no fixed form or boundary, being inexhaustible, 'speak of it as great and the world cannot contain it, speak of it as small and the world cannot split it.'

When Mencius said 'the Way of Yao and Shun is simply filial piety and brotherly respect,' he was pointing to the place where a person's innate knowing manifests most genuinely, earnestly, and deeply—where it cannot be obscured—in order to awaken people. In all of one's dealings—serving the ruler, treating friends, being humane to the people, loving all things—and in all one's movements and silences, speech and reticence—it is always simply extending that one thought of genuine, sincere, compassionate innate knowing of serving parents and following elders. Then naturally nothing is not the Way. For though the affairs of the world change in a thousand ways and ten thousand transformations, beyond all exhaustion, if one simply extends this one thought of genuine, sincere, compassionate innate knowing of serving parents and following elders to respond to them—then there is never any deficiency or gap. This is precisely because there is only this one innate knowing. Beyond the one thought of innate knowing in serving parents and following elders, there is no further innate knowing to extend. Therefore it says: 'The Way of Yao and Shun is simply filial piety and brotherly respect.' This is why it constitutes the learning of 'refinement and singleness,' applicable everywhere under the Four Seas, practiced in all later generations without limit.

Wenwei says: 'I wish to seek the learning of innate knowing in the context of serving parents and following elders.' Spoken in terms of one's own effort where one has found power—this is acceptable. But if one says: 'extend the genuine sincerity and compassionate concern of innate knowing in order to fully realize the Way of serving parents and following elders'—this too is acceptable. Cheng Hao said: 'Practicing humaneness begins with filial piety and brotherly respect. Filial piety and brotherly respect are one aspect of humaneness. To call them the foundation of practicing humaneness is acceptable; to call them the foundation of humaneness is not.' His statement is correct.

Regarding the teaching on 'second-guessing, suspecting, and perceiving first,' Wenwei says: 'If one is sincere, then all indirect and roundabout precautions are the function of innate knowing.' Excellent! Excellent! There are places where he still blends and combines, as I have already discussed above. Weijun's words are also not without merit. For Wenwei to be complete, he must take something from Weijun's words; for Weijun to be clear, he must take something from Wenwei's words. Otherwise, each will inevitably have the disease of one-sided attachment. When Shun 'examined common sayings and consulted the lowly,' it was not that common sayings deserved to be examined and the lowly deserved to be consulted, and therefore he did so. Rather, his innate knowing manifested and flowed, luminous, complete, and unobstructed—this is why it is called great knowledge. The moment there is attachment, insistence, or arbitrariness, knowledge becomes small. In the course of discussing learning, there are naturally discriminations of accepting and rejecting. Yet in terms of applying real effort on the ground of the mind, it must be like this to be correct.

Regarding the 'three sections on fully developing the mind,' I have previously discussed the doctrine of 'born knowing, learning and then knowing, and knowing through difficulty.' This was already quite clear, with nothing to doubt. 'Fully developing the mind, knowing the nature, and knowing Heaven'—one need not then speak of 'preserving the mind, nourishing the nature, and serving Heaven,' nor of 'not being of two minds about longevity, cultivating oneself to await destiny,' for the effort of 'preserving the mind and nourishing the nature' and 'cultivating oneself to await' is already contained within it. 'Preserving the mind, nourishing the nature, and serving Heaven'—though one has not yet reached the level of 'fully developing the mind and knowing Heaven,' one is already doing the effort of seeking to reach that level. One need not then speak of 'not being of two minds about longevity, cultivating oneself to await,' for the effort of 'not being of two minds and cultivating oneself to await' is already contained within it. By analogy with traveling: 'fully developing the mind and knowing Heaven' is like a person in the prime of life who can already run back and forth over thousands of miles. 'Preserving the mind and serving Heaven' is like a child learning to walk within the courtyard. 'Not being of two minds and cultivating oneself to await' is like an infant in swaddling clothes, just beginning to hold onto walls and edges, gradually learning to stand and take steps. One who can already run back and forth over thousands of miles need not be made to practice walking in the courtyard—he can naturally walk in the courtyard without difficulty. One who can already walk in the courtyard need not be made to hold onto walls and learn to stand and take steps—standing and taking steps are naturally easy for him. Yet learning to stand and take steps is the beginning of learning to walk in the courtyard; learning to walk in the courtyard is the foundation of learning to run back and forth over thousands of miles. They are fundamentally not two things, but the difficulty of effort differs vastly. The mind, the nature, and Heaven are one. Therefore, in achieving knowledge and accomplishment, they are one. Yet the three represent different levels of human capacity—there are stages that cannot be skipped.

Looking carefully at Wenwei's argument, his intention seems to fear that those who 'fully develop the mind and know Heaven' might abandon the effort of 'preserving the mind and cultivating the self,' thereby making it a deficiency in 'fully developing the mind and knowing Heaven.' This is worrying about the sage's effort being interrupted, without knowing to worry about one's own effort not being genuine. In our own effort, we should focus single-mindedly on the level of 'not being of two minds and cultivating oneself to await.' This itself is the beginning of the effort of 'fully developing the mind and knowing Heaven'—just as learning to stand and take steps is the beginning of learning to run a thousand miles. I am still worrying about my inability to stand and take steps—how could I already worry about being unable to run a thousand miles? And how much less could one who can run a thousand miles worry about forgetting the habit of standing and taking steps! Wenwei's insight is originally transcendent and extraordinary. That his discussion goes as it does is because he has not yet been able to shed the old habit of interpreting texts. He is trying to analyze, compare, and reconcile these three passages, seeking to blend them into coherence, and in doing so adds many entangling opinions of his own—this instead makes his effort unfocused. Those who recently suspend themselves in emptiness doing 'do not forget, do not help' have precisely this problem in their thinking. It is most apt to delay people and must be washed away.

Regarding the section on 'honoring the moral nature and following the path of inquiry and study'—this is perfectly appropriate and unified, without any further doubt. This shows that Wenwei has indeed applied solid effort, and only then can he make such a statement. This is originally not an abstruse or difficult principle. If others disagree, it is because their innate knowing still has fine veils lurking beneath the surface. Once these veils are removed, everything becomes perfectly transparent.

After finishing the letter, I moved to lie under the eaves. Finding myself with nothing to do, I continued with this reply. Since Wenwei's learning has already grasped the essentials, these matters should in time resolve themselves naturally. There is really no need to analyze point by point like this. But receiving such generous affection, with a messenger sent from a thousand miles, pressing earnest questions—to send him back empty-handed, I could not restrain my words. Yet my directness and prolixity have been excessive. Trusting in your affection, I hope this will not be held against me. Please also have copies transcribed and forwarded to Weijun, Qianzhi, and Chongyi—this further extends the bond of our shared commitment.

Recorded by Nan Daji.

General Principles for Instructing the Young, Presented to the Tutors Liu Bosong and Others

The ancients taught the content of human relationships. In later ages, the habits of rote memorization and literary composition arose, and the teaching of the former kings was lost. In teaching children today, one should take filial piety, brotherly respect, loyalty, trustworthiness, propriety, righteousness, integrity, and a sense of shame as the sole focus. As for the method of nurturing and cultivation, one should draw them through singing poetry to arouse their aspirations, guide them through practicing rituals to dignify their deportment, and encourage them through reading to open their awareness. People today often consider singing poetry and practicing rituals as impractical for current needs. These are all vulgar and base views of a degenerate age—how could they suffice to understand the ancients' intention in establishing education?

In general, children's natural disposition is to delight in play and dread restraint. They are like plants just beginning to sprout: give them room to expand and they will flourish; crush and bend them and they will wither. In teaching children, one must make them tend toward enthusiasm and encouragement, feeling joy in their hearts—then their progress cannot be stopped. It is like timely rain and spring breezes moistening plants and trees: none fail to sprout and flourish, naturally growing day by day and transforming month by month. But if subjected to frost and ice stripping them bare, their vitality becomes desolate, and daily they approach withering and decay.

Therefore, drawing children through singing poetry serves not only to arouse their aspirations, but also to release their jumping, shouting, and calling through song, and to express their pent-up frustrations through melody. Guiding them through practicing rituals serves not only to dignify their deportment, but also to invigorate their blood through bowing and yielding, and to firm their sinews and bones through kneeling, rising, bending, and stretching. Encouraging them through reading serves not only to open their awareness, but also to settle their minds through deep immersion and repeated reflection, and to express their aspirations through the rising and falling cadences of recitation. All of this serves to guide their aspirations smoothly, regulate their temperaments, imperceptibly dissolve their meanness and stinginess, and silently transform their coarseness and stubbornness—daily drawing them toward propriety and righteousness without their feeling it burdensome, entering into centrality and harmony without their knowing how it happened. This is the subtle intention of the former kings in establishing education.

As for those who teach young children in recent times, they do nothing all day but press them with parsing sentences and copying exercises, demanding restraint without knowing how to guide them through ritual, seeking their cleverness without knowing how to nourish them with goodness, whipping and binding them as if treating prisoners. The children view the school as a prison and refuse to enter it; they view the teacher as an enemy and do not wish to see him. They peek and hide and cover up to pursue their play; they devise tricks and pretenses to indulge their stubbornness. They become slovenly, common, and debased, daily sinking lower. This is driving them toward evil while demanding they be good. How can it be achieved?

All that I teach is truly directed at this concern. I fear that the customs of the age will not perceive it and will regard it as impractical. Moreover, as I am about to depart, I specially and earnestly state this to you all. You tutors must embody my intention, uphold it permanently as your standard, and never, on account of the words of prevailing custom, alter or abandon these guidelines. Thus may the work of 'nurturing correctness through childhood instruction' be achieved. Remember this! Remember this!

Rules for Education

Every morning, after the students have assembled and made their bows, the tutor shall in turn inquire of each student: At home, has your heart of loving, respecting, and standing in awe of your parents been without any slackening or inability to be genuine? In the ceremonies of keeping parents warm, keeping them cool, and paying morning and evening visits, has there been any deficiency or failure to practice genuinely? In your bearing and deportment when coming and going in the streets, has there been any looseness or failure to be careful and proper? In all your words, actions, and inner thoughts, has there been any deceit, falsity, or deviation, any failure to be loyal, trustworthy, earnest, and reverent? All the children must answer truthfully. Where there are faults, correct them; where there are none, strive all the harder. The tutor shall then, adapting to the time and the situation, offer thorough instruction and guidance. After this, each shall retire to his seat to continue his studies.

In singing poetry, one must compose one's countenance and settle one's breath, make the voice clear and resonant, and keep the rhythm even and well-modulated—not hasty or rushed, not dissipated or clamorous, not dispirited or timid. Over time, the spirit will be free-flowing and the heart and vital force will be harmonious and peaceful. In each school, divide the students into four groups according to their number. Each day one group sings poetry in rotation, while the rest sit properly with respectful attention. Every five days, all four groups sing in succession at the school. On the first and fifteenth of each month, students from all schools gather to sing together at the academy.

In practicing rituals, one must settle the mind and compose one's thoughts, carefully observing the ceremonial forms and measuring one's bearing—not hasty or negligent, not dejected or embarrassed, not abrupt or uncouth. One should be composed without becoming slow or roundabout, careful without becoming rigid or constrained. Over time, ritual deportment will become second nature and moral character will become firmly established. The grouping of students follows the same pattern as for singing poetry. Every other day, one group practices rituals in rotation, while the rest sit properly with respectful attention. On days of ritual practice, regular copying exercises are excused. Every ten days, all four groups practice in succession at the school. On the first and fifteenth of each month, students from all schools gather to practice together at the academy.

In assigning texts for reading, one should not aim merely at quantity but value thorough mastery. Gauge the student's capacity: if he can handle two hundred characters, assign only one hundred. Always ensure his spirit and energy have something in reserve—then there will be no affliction of weariness and bitterness, but rather the beauty of self-attainment. During recitation, one must insist on single-minded concentration, with the mouth reciting and the mind pondering, unraveling and reviewing each word and phrase, modulating the rising and falling of the voice, keeping the mind open and spacious. Over time, the meaning and principles will be thoroughly absorbed, and intelligence will open daily.

The daily schedule of effort: first, examining moral conduct; next, reciting texts from memory and reading aloud; next, practicing rituals or doing copying exercises; next, reviewing, reciting, and explaining texts; finally, singing poetry. All activities such as practicing rituals and singing poetry serve to constantly preserve the child's heart, making them delight in learning without tiring, so that they have no leisure to turn toward what is deviant or depraved. If the teacher proceeds in this manner, he will know how to apply his efforts. Nevertheless, this is only the general outline. To apply it with spiritual insight and illumination—that depends upon the person.
